Proposed rehabilitation consists of approximately 75.0 meters of trenchless technology through storm sewer lining repair including improvements to outfall structure. By repairing the existing pipe leak, further erosion of the base and bank will be addressed. This will improve the health and safety and environmental conditions; reduce flooding risk through the rehabilitation of the sewer pipe and outfall; and extend the lifecycle of the trunk sewer pipe and outfall structure assets. The trunk storm sewer pipe and outfall structure services a catchment area of approximately 75 hectares consisting of industrial land uses. The project would be integrated with the proposed road reconstruction occurring on Armstrong Avenue.

properties.Name: Water Reservoir Rehabilitation and technical / operational rebuild (Michipicoten River Village)
properties.Description:
Project Description:***Modified project*** See notes for original project information. The Wawa water treatment system treats water in Wawa and distributes it to 3,000 residents and 110 businesses. Some are located in the Michipicoten River Village which is an additional small urban hamlet in Wawa. Due to the distance the treated water must travel and for fire protection purposes, a water reservoir was installed at this location. Recently, this reservoir was identified as requiring a complete rehabilitation, including a complete relining of the tank and the installation of up to date equipment. The rehabilitation will allow the continued operation of the reservoir to provide a safe source of drinking water to the residents located in the Michipicoten River Village. This rehabilitation may also assist in mitigating the causes of the Trihalomethanes that plague the entire drinking water system. This project is a priority for the Municipality of Wawa. Addition scope change to replace the exterior lining of the Michipicoten River Village water tower. It has been sometime since any rehabilitaion work has been done on this asset. Significant work has been done with the Ministry of the Environment on the issue of Trihalomethnanes which are currently present in the water. The proposed work is to assist with alleviating this problem. Other rehabilitation work is required on the inside of the reservoir to protect it from freeze /thaw cycles which result in sediment from the reservoir walls. While the project was being done to complete interior lining, it was noted that the base where the tank is sitting on had started to corrode causing water to get between the tank and the concrete slab, this additional work is required to be completed while exterior lining is being complete and has raised the overall cost of the project to estimate from first request of $225,000.00 to $265,000.00. Extension Rationale:Project was delayed until summer 2018 to complete other portion due to weather conditions.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-11
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Construction of Phase 1 of Loretta Avenue North and South Integrated Road-Sewer-Water Renewal Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:Loretta Ave is currently serviced by combined sewers that are require to be separated to reduce combined sewer overflows by several hundred litres per year to the Ottawa River. There are 965 metres of combine sewers of sizes ranging from 225 mm to 300 mm built in 1930 that will be replaced with separate new sanitary and new storm sewers. There are no sewer needs in Laurel St. There are 1050 metres of watermains built in 1925 ranging in size from 152 - 200 mm in Loretta Ave and Laurel St require replacement due to poor condition and presence of lead services. Full road reconstruction including curbs and sidewalks will also be included with the project.
Construction Start Date:2016-05-09
Construction End Date:2018-11-30

properties.Name: Garner Road Biosolids Management Facility Upgrade - Digester Mixers Replacement - located in the City of Niagara Falls
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Garner Rd. Biosolids facility requires the construction of external mixers on the digester tanks to reduce settling. These external mixers and associated appurtenances will replace the internal mixing system process which has reached the end of its service life. There are three (3) storage tanks that contain 8,000 m³ of sanitary treatment plant sludge each. The sludge must be mixed effectively, otherwise material will settle out and stop the treatment process. The current digester mixing system has significant and ongoing maintenance problems. Not only does this cause problems with the treatment of Biosolids from Regional facilities but in addition to this, the Region has an agreement to supply 5,400 dry tonnes of de-watered biosolids annually to a local firm that produces soil amendment products, which is regulated by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency. When the Region is not able to meet the agreed upon tonnage we must pay the firm $527.37 per ton for the shortage. In summary, Niagara Region is experiencing high maintenance costs and is facing an imminent contractual agreement issue if the mixing system is not replaced.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-24
Construction End Date:2019-05-29

properties.Name: Old Orchard Pump Station Upgrade (forcemain/valve & bypass chamber/pumps/piping/security/electrical/instruments) - located in the Town of Grimsby
properties.Description:
Project Description:"The project includes:  Forcemain replacement  Valve and bypass chamber  Pumps (two)  Process piping  Security upgrade (e.g. gates and hatches),  Electrical control panel complete with a new weather shelter  Instrumentation controls. The total project cost of $2,600,000 is inclusive of all cost to deliver the project including design. The federal and provincial CWWF contributions are based solely on the construction costs. The project is incremental in nature in that even though a design was near completion, the project had been removed from our 2017 capital budget due to insufficient regional funding required to proceed with the construction phase. The CWWF funding will allow us to proceed with a key infrastructure project. Old Orchard Sewage Pumping Station (SPS) was constructed in 1985 and services a small neighborhood community of 400 people in a highly desirable Lake Ontario shoreline area of Grimsby. This pumping station has a history of sanitary spills to the environment (Lake Ontario) as a result of increase flows from wet weather events (rain). It appears that this problem is being exacerbated by the impacts of climate change. In addition the pumping station has reached the end of its service life and this is compounding the challenge to transfer the increased volume of sewage to the Baker Road Wastewater Treatment Plant. This project will reduce CSO (Combined Sewer Overflows) to the lake and beach front areas as well as extending the capabilities of the station to meet Levels of Service for another 20 years. "
Construction Start Date:2017-02-21
Construction End Date:2018-02-21

properties.Name: Thornbury Wastewater Treatment Plant Ultraviolet (UV) Replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** The objective of this project is to replace the existing older Ultraviolet (UV) Unit at the Thornbury Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) that has reached the end of its useful life with current technology. The scope of work is to engage a consulting engineer to complete the detailed design and associated tendering and construction administration tasks culminating in the selection of a contractor and the removal of the existing units, modification to existing electrical plant and installation of the replacement UV unit. During final design it was discovered that the concrete channel required improvements and adjustments to allow for more efficient operations of the new UV. In addition, an effluent level controller to minimize variations in flow to keep lamps at an ideal operating submersion and an operator SCADA interface was required at the UV panel. It was also identified that more programming was required for Module Communication Alarms. For health and safety reasons, a module lifting device was added which included a davit crane, base and lifting sling, hand winch including an adjustable boom and a swivel handle for rotation and positioning of the UV units. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope that will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $128,353.50 to be reallocated from TBM-001.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-06
Construction End Date:2018-05-31

This upgrade will maximize the allowable Permit To Take Water firm pumping capacity in the Alliston system; and expand the associated chlorine contact chamber for required disinfection processes for the additional water supply. These upgrades will increase the security of water supply in order to meet today's current residents and business supply demands and as our community evolves and grows ensuring provincial water quality parameters are met for the increase in water supply (servicing a population of 24,800 for Alliston and Beeton). Original timeframe for these works was anticipated for 2020, and as a result of this funding the project can now be expedited to allow earlier implementation in order to optimize the well's pumping capacity and associated disinfection processes.

properties.Name: Radio Communication System for Raw Water Pumping Station
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will purchase and install a radio communication system to eliminate the possibility of malfunction of the leased line modem connection. This will ensure the safe operation of the plant and will reduce operating costs by eliminating the ongoing cost of a leased telephone line. A recent malfunction required the operators to monitor the Water Treatment Plant 24/7 for 2 weeks until repairs could be made and also required the manual making of water. This was very time consuming and created many inefficiencies. Improved environmental outcome: With the communications failure we recently experienced, we had to run the plant and the raw water station manually which is the least energy efficient way of doing it. It means we have to manually throttle pumps and filter trains decreasing efficiency, and in the case of the raw water station to run the pumps manually we had to run them without Variable Frequency Drive (VFDs), which means they are running at 100% output and using the most energy. This project could eliminate these problems.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Golden Pheasant Wastewater Treatment Plant - Upgrade, Optimization and rehabilitation of Preliminary and Secondary Treatment processes
properties.Description:
Project Description:To address aging infrastructure, and effluent quality issues , and to ensure cost effective operations, the District has a long term strategy to decommission the existing Huntsville Mountview Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) (which does not meet Federal or Provincial Regulations) , and divert all Huntsville flows to the Golden Pheasant WWTP. This project will initiate the first phase of this long term strategy which is to upgrade the Golden Pheasant WWTP in preparation for accepting additional flows. The Golden Pheasant WWTP projects includes the following components: Upgrades to a septage receiving system to replace a dysfunctional system and enable monitoring of the load received to protect the treatment plant performance and reliability. Replacement of the existing jet aeration system with a fine bubble aeration system, to rehabilitate an aging system and improve reliability and efficiency. Modification and extension of the existing biological reactor to provide ability to reliably nitrify and produce a non-toxic effluent with respect to ammonia (to comply with provincial requirements), and to provide a de-nitrification cell to enhance energy efficiency and alkalinity recovery, to minimize the need for alkalinity addition to meet effluent pH criteria. Addition of a new chemical building and system for alkalinity addition to top up alkalinity (that cannot be fully recovered through denitrification) and reliability meet effluent pH criteria. Addition of a waste activated sludge (WAS) thickening facility to provide sludge management capacity at Golden Pheasant WWTP that will be required to accommodate Mountview WWTP flows. This approach is significantly lower cost than expanding anaerobic digester capacity that will otherwise be required.
Construction Start Date:2016-10-24
Construction End Date:2018-09-14

properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Based on a refined cost estimate, it's anticipated that the project will be completed under budget. Seeking ability to move the excess funds to another approved project with an increased scope of delivery. The City's buildings, facilities and park sites include buried infrastructure that requires complete inventory updates, condition and performance assessment in order to develop a risk based inspection and rehabilitation/renewal plan. This project will update the inventory of pipes that and appurtenances that lie within the property boundaries of city-owned facilities, yards, garages, parks and buildings. The size, dimension and material of buried sewer and water mains within the property boundaries are poorly documented and this project will build inventory data and confidence in that data. This will help with future planning and coordination of interventions as supported by the City's asset management program. The City has roughly 1,500 properties where investigation would be required. The process to complete the design for work of this magnitude requires time and we are requesting an extension to the program March 31, 2018 deadline IO NOTE: There is no decrease in scope, but a decrease in tender. This will result in a decrease in Federal Funding of $125,000 to be reallocated to OTT-005."
Construction Start Date:2017-05-23
Construction End Date:2019-10-01

properties.Name: Rivervale Water and Street Lighting Service Water System Intake Upgrades
properties.Description:

properties.Name: Cowichan Water Supply Structured Decision Model (SDM) Development
properties.Description:
Project Description:The proposed project by the Cowichan Valley Regional District (CVRD) will move the planning process forward by using a structured development model (SDM) approach to determine the volume required for future storage. The SDM process will ensure that whatever the recommended storage and management options chosen will meet the anticipated environmental and public consultation requirements of a conservation license application. The objective of this project is to develop and build a long term component of the regions infrastructure that is both current and future focused.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-08
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Watermain Looping Completion for Village of Bourget
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Drinking Water Distribution for expansion to accommodate existing infrastructure pressures. Under the Infrastructure Stimulus Funding program, the City of Clarence-Rockland was able in 2010-11 to extend watermain infrastructure into two main rural villages and distribute to most residents within villages, however provisions for watermain looping were deemed unaffordable at the time. This project will complete a watermain looping for the village of Bourget, (preference is to complete both villages). A new section of 300mm watermain of 4.4 km in length on Russell Road between Gendron Rd. and Marcil Rd. will loop that village's drinking water network. Over 30 additional residences will enjoy access to drinking water. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."

Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Christina Lake Water System Upgrades

properties.Name: Upgrade to the Main Sewage Pumping Station - Roy Street Sewage Lift/Pumping Station, including Pumps, Piping and Controls
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project includes the replacement of all the internal components of the sewage lift station, including the pumps, steel piping and controls. This is being replaced due to the existing system being significantly corroded and rusted, which could result in a failure of the piping network and pumping system. This in the main sewage pumping station for the Township of Emo, which collects all the sewage from the entire Town, so failure of this station would be catastrophic. The pumping station will be fitted with stainless steel piping which is more resistant to corrosion, and the new pumps will be updated to be able to handle appropriate flows from the expanding Township. The works associated with this project have no yet commenced due to lack of funding. With this funding, the Town can move forward with this very important project.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

The proposed work will improve the reliability of aged and worn equipment extending the functionality of the asset and help ensure that the natural environment is protected. Protection of public health and safety is also provided to the connected users in that the rehabilitation will help ensure that sewage does not backup into basements.

As the Seacliff Trunk sanitary sewer currently accepts sanitary and combined sewage from the southern portion of Leamington, servicing additional areas is not permitted by the Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change regardless of available capacity. Once the Seacliff Trunk sanitary sewer is fully separated, it will allow for future sanitary servicing of existing homes and properties along Lake Erie that are currently using septic systems.

properties.Name: Colver St. and Wade Rd.Lateral Assessments and Pipe Rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:Pipe rehabilitation from Manhole 72 to 75 ( Canborough St.) to Manhole 75 to 76 (Wade Rd.). The total proposed works are for the construction and installation of a structural liner, grouting, and miscellaneous service repairs in the road allowance. This is a recommended 'no-dig' solution that reduces the impact to the area and reduced impact to the environment. The proposed works to the sewer main are also in preparation for a future project to remove inflow in this critical area. These works will be part of a series of works needed in order to achieve an ultimate goal of MOECC F-5-5 compliance. The structural liners are expected to add approximately 50 years to the life expectancy of the sewers.moderately severe and has been identified as a priority area. In 2014 - 2015 the Township completed an Inflow and Infiltration Flow Monitoring and CCTV study on its existing sanitary sewer system. The study identified key areas of sanitary sewer where deficiencies were identified including high levels of infiltration during peak wet weather events. This included sewers on Station Street, Colver Street, and Wade Road. The study noted high level event coefficient of variation (CV) of up to 15.5%, or severe. The study recommends that the areas are critical and need to be considered a priority. Additional CCTV inspections confirmed multiple sources of infiltration, including cracks, displaced joints, and infiltration gushers. A review of the sewer deficiencies determined that a full structural and service repairs within the road allowance is the best approach.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Village of Chipman Wastewater Treatment Facility Upgrades
properties.Description:

Design and construct a new outfall to the Salmon River, effluent pumping station and forecemain, disinfection process, equipment enclosures, electrical upgrades, and an interceptor drainage trench to redirect groundwater from the proposed wastewater treatment facility site. These upgrades will benefit the current wastewater treatment facility as well as a future wastewater treatment facility.

This watermain, together with the other river crossing on Bridge St, service approximately 3500 residents. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."

properties.Name: Design and purchase of Organic Rankine Cycle equipment for Power Generation and Waste Heat Recovery Systems & Biosolids Optimization at Greenway Pollution Control Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "The main focus of this project will involve the pre-purchase of the critical components including an Organic Rankine Cycle engine power unit and heat exchanger, preliminary building modifications and process and electrical designs to generate 450 kW of electricity from waste heat recovered from the Greenway biosolids incinerator. A secondary component is a study to evaluate the potential to use waste heat from the incineration process to replace several natural gas Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) units; the study will also evaluate the plant's end of life hydronic heating piping system and any upgrades needed to handle additional heating loads. Biosolids Optimization Study: Currently 40% of the biosolids generated in the City of London are dewatered to 3-4 % solids at satellite plants then trucked to Greenway for incineration. This study will evaluate the feasibility of dewatering those solids to 25% solids at the satellite plants before transportation to Greenway thereby reducing the number of loads from approximately 7000 per year to 2000. Waste Heat Utilization and Optimization: The Greenway plant currently uses waste heat from the biosolids incinerator to heat most plant buildings and spaces through a hydronic heating system; however, there are several natural gas fired HVAC units onsite that can potentially be converted to utilize the hydronic system. A study will evaluate the feasibility of converting the natural gas units to the hydronic systems as well as any upgrades needed. This system is independent of the proposed Organic Rankine Cycle system. Future projects will be identified. During the design phase it was discovered that the addition of Rotating Drum Thickener (RDT) is required to accommodate tight space requirements of the Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) with new access to penthouse required.
Construction Start Date:2016-07-25
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Harmony Creek Water Pollution Control Plant Upgrades, including aeration system, secondary clarifier,  waste gas burner, Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition system and  operations building.
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Harmony Creek Water Pollution Control Plant services approximately 75,000 residents for the City of Oshawa and the Municipality of Clarington (Courtice). The project is the final phase of upgrades required to operate the plant for the next twenty years. The project will identify and undertake upgrades to the following elements: aeration system, secondary clarifier, sludge heating, sludge storage tanks, gas room modifications, waste gas burner, sludge thickening  mechanical, Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system and plant operations building. March 2019 extension - the Region has requested extension to accommodate the lead time to apply and receive regulatory approvals, procure equipment and extensive construction schedule due to the complexity of the projects

properties.Name: Replace 15 Main Valves Within the Water Distribution System
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will replace 15 main valves in the water distribution system and includes restoration of roads where excavation occurs with an aim of increasing efficiency. Distribution system - 15 main valves broken (8 Water Mains Control Valves for Isolating the system). Currently there are locations in town where, if we have an issue, we are forced to shut off up to 6 valves where only 2 would have been required if all the valves were working. This increases the number of residences affected during a shut-off situation and makes the work far more complicated. Improved environmental outcome: Control & Management of treated water; Reduction of waste of treated water; Reduction of contamination to ground due to current leaks and reduce the amount of water and energy needed for production to make up for any losses. As a result, less treatment chemicals are used; Reduction of ground excavating due to current water leaks and reduction of the water wasted to drain a water main to perform repairs.

properties.Name: Mary street sewer main rehabilitation & storm water infiltration prevention.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Relining of badly deteriorating clay 250mm sewer main. Deterioration includes cracks, which are leading to high levels of storm water and some known contaminants infiltrating into the main. Also blockage inhibitors such as calcite buildup & high levels of storm water. Four (4) old cracked & infiltrating sewer manholes will also be relined. The rehabilitation of approximately 290 m of sewer main will turn failing clay main into 290 m of new reinforced plastic sewer main as well as turning 4 leaking & cracking manholes into 4 new water tight manholes. Project also includes the replacement of 4 undersized 1940's storm catch basins with 4 new larger capacity basins to provide cleaner water & reduce street flooding. This section of Mary ST sewer main directly services 7 households, 1 recreation facility, 14 Commercial addresses, 4 apartment units & is ultimately a trunk line for another 12 addresses.

This 550m section of watermain has experienced 15 watermain breaks and has resulted in service interruption to houses fronting Srigley Street and the Retirement Residence at the corner of Srigley and Leslie Street. The watermain repairs involve excavation in the eastbound curb lane where the Town will be constructing the On-Street Bike Lane as part of the Active Transportation Network (ATN). This section of ATN is receiving Provincial funding contingent upon completion in 2017. Therefore this watermain requires immediate rehabilitation. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.

properties.Name: Ashern Wastewater System
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project is to address large amounts of groundwater and precipitation entering the lagoon through the municipal system. Approximately two kilometres of wastewater lines will be replaced. The project will also include necessary manhole repairs. "REVISED PROJECT DESCRIPTION: The purpose of the project is to address large amounts of groundwater and precipitation entering the lagoon through the municipal system. A new cell will be constructed adjacent to the existing lagoon in order to address capacity. The project will also include necessary manhole repairs. Rationale for Scope Change: During the design phase of the project, engineers determined that the replacement of wastewater sewer lines would not adequately address the lagoon capacity issues caused by ground water and precipitation, nor would it address extreme infiltration during high water periods. The lagoon would still need to be expanded to address the capacity and infiltration issue. In order to increase capacity and address the infiltration issue, the engineer recommend constructing an additional cell, adjacent to the existing lagoon instead of replacing the water lines. The proposed scope change will address the lagoon capacity issues. The revised scope would be to address large amounts of groundwater and precipitation entering the lagoon through the municipal system. A new cell will be constructed adjacent to the existing lagoon in order to address capacity. The project will also include necessary manhole repairs.

properties.Name: Seasonal wastewater lagoon optimization
properties.Description:
Project Description:We are not able to discharge the seasonal wastewater lagoons according to regulation and untreated wastewater is entering the environment. Seasonal discharge has not been done in 4 years. At this time, there are uncontrolled overflows from the lagoon to the environment. The outfall stations pumps are no longer working. The engineering study, which is not part of the scope of this project, is underway and scheduled to be complete by September 2017. The engineering study will determine if installing a pressure-fed or gravity-fed system is best to optimize the seasonal discharge. From the study, a solution will be determined and designed. From there, the capital works and types of pumps, pipes and electrical systems we will be purchased and installed, as well as the design specifications (gradient, diameter, and materials) will be determined through the study recommendations. The completion of the lagoon optimization will ensure that untreated wastewater does not enter the environment or negatively impact surrounding and off-reserve communities.

properties.Name: Snow Disposal Facility Upgrade
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Most of Guelph's drinking water comes from the ground. The City of Guelph's existing Snow Disposal Facility (SDF) requires upgrades to meet provincial best-practices and ensure Guelph's groundwater is protected. Improvements to the facility include an asphalt or clay base, drainage and settling ponds, fencing, and a separate entrance that can be locked during off-hours. An upgrade to the Snow Disposal Facility supports the Federal Government's goal of fostering economic growth and a cleaner and healthier environment, the Province's Source Water Protection legislation, and the City's Groundwater Protection program by reducing the introduction of contaminants and silt from melting snow into water sources such as the Speed River and aquifers. The upgrade will bring the City into compliance with the Province's best practices for the operation of a snow disposal facility and the improvements will enable more efficient operation while ensuring greater safety. The Snow Disposal Facility is used by City departments and third-party contractors for excess snow disposal and in the Spring for stockpiling street-sweepings until removal and disposal under approved contract. Given the proximity of the SDF to source water vulnerability in Guelph, staff determined that improvements to the site were necessary. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change confirmed in 2015 that the City needs to upgrade its Snow Disposal Facility as soon as possible to meet the Province's best practices. Pre-studies and pre-design work has been approved by council with work ready to begin in Q4 of 2016 with construction from September to November 2017. Due to regulatory requirements and/or permit delays, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."

This construction project will involve enlarging the storage basin for the pond and reconstructing the outlet facility to control flows as designed. The $250,000 increase in total project costs (i.e. $125,000 in federal CWWF funding) reflects the increased cost to cover additional project components to the stormwater management pond landscaping treatments and a greater volume of soil management (disposal from excavation of the pond) identified in the recently completed Environmental Assessment. In 2010, Plant 1 was taken out of service due to significant water leakage within the Plant 1 clearwell. In 2015, the Region identified the need to restore the capacity of the Oshawa Water Supply Plant to 134 ML/D by rehabilitation of Plant 1. properties.Name: Seaway Wastewater Treatment Plant Aeration Blower Replacement (including surge supression) - located in the City of Port Colbornet
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Seaway Wastewater Treatment Plant located in the City of Port Colborne treats sewage from approximately 13,650 residents plus industrial, commercial and institutional sewage generators. This Wastewater Treatment Plant is a Class 3 plant with a rated Average Daily Flow capacity of 19,600 m³/day, Peak Flow Rate (Dry Weather) of 45,360 m³/day. This treatment plant was built in 1981. The plant's mechanical aeration system was replaced in 2010 with a fine bubbler system. However the Port Colborne area often has power outages that cause issues with the plant's electrical equipment. Because of this problem the aeration blowers were damaged during a power outage. A temporary multistage centrifuge blower was installed to keep the plant in operation until a more permanent solution could be identified. An engineering study was done to analyze the spare aeration blower capabilities and recommend a solution to ensure Ministry of Environment compliance. The study concluded that the spare aeration blower is not adequate to meet the rated capacity of the plant, and need to be replaced with properly sized aeration blowers. Also the installation of appropriate surge suppression technology will be built at this plant to prevent re-occurrence. The following are the main components of the project:  Installation of new blowers (3 or 4 units depending on equipment suppliers specifications) to provide air to the fine bubbler system.  Installation of surge suppression equipment to provide electrical protection for the blower assemblies. The cost estimate is based on the consultant study. Total estimated project cost is $800,000 based on the projected 9 year capital forecast.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-30
Construction End Date:2019-05-29

Works will include sewers, roadway, sidewalks and lighting. The project affects the existing 65 homes that are currently serviced by an aging combination sewer that flows downstream to a separated sewer system. The eligible costs are limited to public/municipal property and assets. Reason for Variance - 1) Original project estimate submitted to the CWWF was prepared before final design/engineering had started. The project estimate was largely based on average sewer/road construction prices in the Leamington area. 2) Three contractors closed tenders for the works, and the difference between the low bid and the 2nd low bid was significant at $544,400. The difference between the 2nd and 3rd low bidders was $60,500. 3) The low bidder was already in the area completing two sewer projects and likely anticipated some savings on mobilization costs. IO NOTE: There is a decrease in tender and will result in an decrease in Federal Funding of $482,888.00 to be reallocated to LEA-005 and LEA-006."

properties.Name: Replacement of Aging/Asbestos Water Supply Pipeline on Scott Street to improve Reliable Access to Safe Drinking Water, and Modernize to Meet Projected Growth
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Current Watermain Situation: The Stayner water system provides water to 3,500 residents and 1,592 residential, commercial and industrial structures. Challenges: The existing 100m diameter pipes from on Scott Avenue from the intersections of Highway 26 & Saunders Street was built in the 1940s. This sections uses 100mm asbestos pipe that has broken 6 times in the last 10 years, contaminating the river with chlorinated water and does not meet fire flow. The 6 pipe failures resulted in an avg. of 7.5hrs of water system downtime and $1000/hr in damages. Project: This project will replace 100 meters (Scott Avenue from HWY 26 to Saunders Street) of existing 100mm diameter piping with heavier, more durable and environmentally friendly 150mm piping that will meet fire flow and help with consistent residential supply and looping. The new pipe will be made from polyvinyl chloride (PVC) replacing the hazardous asbestos pipes. This replacement will reduce/eliminate incidence of water main breakages and leaks caused by current deficient piping failing. Project Impact on Rehabilitating and modernizing Ontarios aging infrastructure: During pipe failures, there is a significant risk of contamination of chlorinated water to the river and loss to flow. The replacement of the pipes to 150mm PVC pipes will provide better flow to fire protection and allow for further extension of reliable supply and looping for future infrastructure for main supply to residents and businesses. Projects Impact on Accelerating Short-Term Community Infrastructure Investments: This project will allow us to better ensure the provision of safe drinking water and adequate water pressures to the growing Stayner community in the future. This project will enhance water capacity, as the increased diameter of the replacement pipe will increase volume capacity. Water volume usage is forecast to grow from 1800 m3/day in 2016 to 3180 m3/day in 2026 (76% growth)."
Construction Start Date:2017-05-01
Construction End Date:2017-11-30

properties.Name: Detailed Wastewater System Assessment and Identification of Alternatives to Meet Guidelines and Future Community Environmental and Health and Safety Needs
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will include the detailed assessment of the communal wastewater collection system at Grassy Narrows First Nation. The current system consists of a network of gravity sewers, five (5) sewage pumping stations, and the connecting forcemain which feeds a Rotating Biological Contactor (RBC) treatment plant which discharges to a dual cell sewage lagoon, as well as. This system network currently services approximately 80% of the community with the remaining population being reliant on individual septic systems. The wastewater plant was designed over 25 years ago to treat wastewater flows up to the year 2011 and is therefore beyond its intended lifecycle and has exceeded its volume and treatment capacity. The lack of capacity to not only meet current, let alone future community needs, is presenting a considerable risk to the health and safety of residents and the environment. It is therefore required that a detailed assessment be completed to identify all existing deficiencies as well as provide upgrade alternatives and future recommendations that will be essential to providing adequate wastewater services to the community. This assessment will also identify possible solutions to removing any immediate and significant health and safety and environmental risks associated with the system being at capacity and consequent negative impacts on the receiving environment. This will ultimately benefit the receiving environment off reserve.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Separation of Combined Sewer System on Lorne Street (Queen St to CPR Railway)
properties.Description:
Project Description:Lorne Street is a collector roadway that serves as one of two major gateways into the Town's industrial area. The existing road, water and sidewalk assets are all in need of replacement making this corridor the Towns top candidate for reconstruction. Properties within the work area (480m stretch from Queen St to the CPR Railway) include 26 homes, two factories and a commercial strip mall. The reconstruction of Lorne Street proposes to include approximately 430m of new storm sewer ranging in size from 600mm to 750mm. This new storm sewer will enable the separation of existing combined sanitary sewers. The existing 300/350mm combined sanitary trunk within this corridor currently accepts surface drainage from an area of 19 hectares. Engineering calculations have identified that separation of this combined sewer has the potential to divert up to 2,600 cubic meters of water out of the wastewater treatment plant during a five year storm event. This diversion meets the objectives of the Towns Pollution Prevention and Control Program and the project will work towards the goals of reducing the scale and frequency of bypasses to secondary treatment at the wastewater treatment plant. The Rideau River is the receiving waterway for the Towns effluent. This federally regulated waterway also carries a UNESCO designation recognized internationally.

Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Replace deterioration culvert and road rehabilitation to ensure safe passage and flow of surface and storm water in the water basin. The increase of $501,165 in total project costs ($250,583 in federal funding) is due to the scope of work being part of a road reconstruction program and the culvert replacement tender price for this scope of work came in higher than the budgetary estimates. In addition, condition of the subbase of the existing wooden box culvert required more extensive reconstruction to accommodate the replacement concrete box culvert. The existing conditions could not be identified during preliminary condition assessments. properties.Name: Storm Extension to College & Crawford allowing for disconnection of combined sewer for storm water
properties.Description:
Project Description:Current situation does not allow for the combined sewer to be disconnected to address the overflow issues arising during rain events because the storm line is too far away. In order to eliminate the overflow onto streets and property causing damage and impacting approximately 924 residents in the area, we need to extend a storm line to the location which is causing the issue. Currently Crawford Avenue and the combined sewer that is serving the area between College Ave and Erie St W is being flooded by storm water from the adjacent rail road (RR) lands. Our preliminary investigation last year indicated that all surface water for this vast RR area was connected directly into our combined sewer. As a result, continuous out letting into the combined sewer has led to flooding in our combined sewer system over the course of several days. During any given heavy rain storm, the pressure of the inflow is so great that it is overflowing out of the manholes causing road flooding over the curbs and into the adjacent warehouses and private property. The proposed separation project would permit us to study how much storm water is entering the system based on the drainage area, engineer the proper drainage/retention in the RR lands and separate the existing combined sewer on Crawford Ave. allowing storm water to enter our storm system via Erie St. and into the College Trunk Storm Sewer. This is a much needed improvement to prevent road flooding, sewer flooding and property damage.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-30

The six (6) new watermain valves will be installed at the 1) & 2) east and west side of the watermain on Wood Street where the watermain connects to the pump house and treatment facility; 3) Located on Mill Street on the 250 mm diameter watermain located on the Mill Street extension of the watermain that runs under the Conestoga River just west of the intersection of Mill Street and River Run Road; 4) Intersection of Wood and John Street on the 150 mm diameter watermain on the north leg of the connection between the Wood Street and John Street watermains; 5) Intersection of Union Street and Smith Drive on the 150 mm diameter watermain on the east leg of the connection between the Union Street and Smith Drive watermains; 6) Intersection of Union Street and Spring Street on the 150 mm diameter watermain on the west leg of the connection between the Union Street and Spring Street watermain. The two (2) replacement valves are located at: 1) Intersection of Wood and John Street on the 250 mm diameter watermain on the west leg of the connection between the Wood Street and John Street watermains; 2) Intersection of Union Street and Main Street on the 150 mm diameter watermain on the south leg of the connection between the Union Street and Main Street watermains

properties.Name: Reduce Lake Erie phosphorus loading rehabilitating 8 wetlands as part of the regional stormwater conveyance and management system
properties.Description:
Project Description:"This project will target the conveyance, treatment and capture of non-point source agricultural stormwater runoff for the purpose of removing/reducing stormwater pollutants and reducing phosphorus loads entering Lake Erie. The project will complete the design and rehabilitation of 8 wetlands which form part of the stormwater conveyance, located in the Lake Erie basin. Works will include replacement or repair of existing inlet and outlet hydraulic control structures; re-grading, re-vegetating, and reconstruction of damaged or dysfunctional drainage channels and wetland berms/banks; and sediment removal from ditches and wetlands to restore treatment volumes and treatment effectiveness, and restore optimal stormwater conveyance. The project will also include the construction of 10 small Constructed Wetland stormwater systems as demonstration sites for testing for stormwater quality improvement for agricultural runoff. Project will contribute to a reduced level of toxic algal blooms for overall improved health of the lake. Due to the magnitude and complexity of the project, an extension beyond March 31, 2018, is requested. The project sites are : 3144 BRIGHAM RD, London; 4163 HWY #3, Cayuga; 766526 TOWNSHIP 5 RD, Blandford-Blenheim; 409 SCENIC DR, South Dumfries; 283 MCLEAN SCHOOL RD, South Dumfries; 4340 LOBSINGER LINE, Wellesley; 5319 ERAMOSA ERIN TOWNLINE, Erin; 5007 THIRD LINE, Erin"

Construction End Date:2018-03-31

This project will result in the development of hydraulic models and detailed engineering analysis of these systems in order to identify any shortcomings in the system which may be present. This information will then be used to inform the District's asset management plan.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-17
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

Approximately 3,250 m of conventional watermain will be constructed within the existing subdivision.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-01

properties.Name: Purchase and installation of stand-by generator for the Saugeen Composite Water tower
properties.Description:
Project Description:Project will supply a permanent, non-portable Generator for the Composite Water Tower. Ice storms knock out the power, often annually for days, and a stationary generator would reduce risk of loss of water services, since it is manual now, and the tower is on a back road away from the main village. Reduces risk to over 800 people in 250+ households in the community as well as providing immediate benefit the 2400 non-Native cottagers who lease land on Saugeen. The Nation will be able to provide certainty in water quality and delivery during high tourist season. This initiative will provide long term benefits for all members by continually assuring the safety and quality of our water tower and water system on a daily basis and moreover in emergency situations and continued assurance of reduced impact on the province's health care system.
Construction Start Date:2017-12-06
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: Increasing Warren Sewage Lift Station reliability by replacing two aging 10 horsepower lift pumps

Project Description:Replacement of two 20 horsepower aging sewage lift pumps to increase sewage system reliability. The current pumps are over 20 years old and there is an increased chance of failure as they get older. By replacing these pumps, we would reduce the likelihood of pump failure and mitigate sewage spills. The sewage lift chamber is otherwise in good condition and this replacement will extend the lifespan of the entire facility.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2017-11-30

properties.Name: Angela Drive & Cecile Drive - Utility & Roadworks Improvements
properties.Description:

Construction End Date:2018-03-15

properties.Name: Supplemental Water Supply System Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project includes the complete planning, design, preparatory capital work and construction of new water supply wells, raw water storage, treatment, iron removal, treated water storage , pumping and monitoring system infrastructure.
Construction Start Date:2018-03-08
Construction End Date:2019-02-26

properties.Name: Lateral inspections to determine the condition of the lateral collection system feed lines from customers.
properties.Description:
Project Description:A collection system inspection was done in 2016 which found that many laterals are leaking. A more extensive study is needed to find all the laterals that are leaking and to make a plan to repair. Also confirm that repairs performed to the distribution system lines have been repaired by inspecting the adjacent collection system lines for infiltration reduction post repair. This water infiltration was first observed during collection system inspections in mid 2016. Objective: To inspect a portion of the system laterals that were identified as potential issues in the Closed-circuit television inspection of the main sewer lines. These laterals show high quantities of material flowing through them and have contributed to excessive water in the sanitary system (and correlating bypass events). The source of this water is unidentified. The objective is to reduce the lateral infiltration component. Scope: To Closed-circuit television the lateral in question, which may include accessing through homes if required, working with the municipality to identify access points and determine the extent of remediation necessary to enable Council to make a decision regarding rehabilitation options. Output: Closed-circuit television video to show the source of leakage within the lateral and a report to detail to findings.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-21
Construction End Date:2017-10-16

properties.Name: Improvements to water distribution through acquiring new water truck
properties.Description:
Project Description:All water is transported by water truck. The current water truck is a high risk and does not meet the community's needs. Project would be to purchase a new water truck for the community. Off-reserve benefits are more secure drinking water system with reduced burden to provincial health system.
Construction Start Date:2018-02-08
Construction End Date:2018-04-18

properties.Name: Repairs and Upgrades at Sewage Lift Stations
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Repairs and upgrades at five sewage lift stations. Conduct a full inspection ,testing and upgrades to all (5) pump control panels. Electrical control specialist to inspect ,test all components to ensure functionality and repair, replace and or upgrade. Conduct a full inspection and testing of all mechanical components including valves , piping, and pumping equipment. Full servicing, repairs and or upgrade of all (5) pumping stations. Pump replacements: a. Lift station#1- (2) New Pumps - FLYGHT-NP3153 - 20hp - 3 PH - 230 V- purchase & freight; Lift station #2- (2) New Pumps - FLYGHT- NP3127- 7.5hp - 3 PH - 230 V- purchase & freight; Lift station #3 - (2) New Pumps - FLYGHT- NP3127- 7.5hp - 1 PH - 230 V- purchase & freight; Lift station #4 - (2) New Pumps - FLYGHT- NP3127- 7.5hp - 1 PH - 230 V- purchase &freight; Lift station #5 - (2) New Pumps - MG200-21P - Purchase & freight; Lift stations #1 to #5 have the pumps serviced and repaired for all 9 pumps; Lift stations #1 to #5 obtain an inventory of spare parts; Lift Station #5 - Install pump control panel and pump rail set up assembly. Currently this pump station is a single pump set-up and is hard piped this upgrade would reduce and simplify maintenance, includes new control panel, controls electrical mechanical materials and set-up. Off-reserve benefit are protection to receiving environment by protecting against overflows due to pump failure. "
Construction Start Date:2017-02-15
Construction End Date:2018-03-01

properties.Name: Water and Sewer Servicing
properties.Description:
Project Description:Install water and sewage servicing lines to connect future Band Office and Elder's Place (i.e. for seniors). Band office and meeting place will be site of economic development and tourism ventures for general public. Off-reserve benefits include ensuring that the health and well-being of the band office employees and seniors are serviced by sufficient potable water to meet their daily needs and minimize use of the provincial health care system through a sufficient supply of clean water which is necessary for proper sanitation and health. Additional off-reserve benefits include providing clean water and sewage services for travellers and off-reserve visitors and tourists.

Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Integrate and upgrade the communication and data management systems at the water and wastewater plants.
properties.Description:

properties.Name: Port Weller Wastewater Treatment Plant - Grit Upgrade Program (Retrofitting the existing air lift pumping system to grit pump and cyclonic grit concentrator) - located in the City of St. Catharines
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Region Wide Grit Upgrade Program supports the rehabilitation/replacement of grit systems at Wastewater Treatment Plants (WWTP). In 2017 the program will carry out upgrades to the Port Weller WWTP grit system. The Port Weller WWTP located in St. Catharines provides wastewater (sanitary) treatment for approximately 75,000 people plus industrial, commercial and institutional needs. This plant is a Class 4 facility and has a rated capacity of 56,180 m³/day with a peak primary treatment flow rate of 136,200 m³/day and a peak secondary treatment flow rate of 112,360 m³/day. The existing air lift system at the plant has reached the end of its service life and will be replaced with a new pumping system. This will include associated piping, wiring and minor SCADA modifications. Retrofitting the existing air lift pumping system to grit pump and cyclonic grit concentrator will reduce hydraulic loading to the classifier and increase grit removal efficiency. The improvements will increase the grit removal from the plant treatment train and reduce grit accumulation in the sludge digesters. Additionally it is expected that there will be reduced maintenance related costs. This is from the reduction in replacement of pump impellers and prolonging the cleanout interval of digesters and aeration tanks. In summary these improvements will increase grit capture by 100% and as a result decrease maintenance costs as well as supporting the treatment plants MOECC obligations (rated capacities). The cost estimate is based on 60% detailed design. Final costs will be subject to tender award.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-15
Construction End Date:2018-10-31

properties.Description:
Project Description:The objective of this project is to replace the rooves of the Thornbury Waste Water Treatment Plant's Administration Building, Inlet Building and Ultra Violet Irradiation Building as well as the replacement of the Administration Building's Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) unit that has reached the end of its useful life. The scope of work is to engage a consulting engineer to complete the detailed design and associated tendering and construction administration tasks culminating in the selection of a contractor and the removal of the existing rooves and installation of the new rooves and the replacement of the HVAC System. The integrity of the operational systems to treat wastewater depends on the soundness of the building facility within it operates. The building envelope, of which the roof is a critical component, protects the treatment equipment from outside elements and is critical to the reliability of equipment. Without a functioning roof in place, water intrusion will lead to electrical failures and corrosion that will dis-able equipment and threaten the plants ability to treat water. Without a sound building housing the equipment, including a sound roof, the treatment plant will be ineffectual.

properties.Name: Design and Construction of Mud Creek Stormwater Measures
properties.Description:
Project Description:The bank along Mud Creek adjacent to a City Works Yard is eroding due to flow path erosion from the works yard to the creek. This project will address the flow path deficiencies from the works yard discharging to the creek and will rehabilitate the eroded creek bank caused by the overall discharge problems. The bank stabilization measures proposed are the direct result of uncontrolled stormwater conveyance to the receiver (Mud Creek), as a result of development. This project will introduce a new stormwater infiltration swale with rock check dams to provide treatment and reduce the flow and velocity of stormwater sheet drainage from the site. As well, the degraded creek bank resulting from the cumulative effects of uncontrolled sheet drainage will be stabilized to ensure a stable outlet for the site as well as a stable shoreline for the creek corridor. The project will include a new rip-rap outlet and sediment trap from the works yard to the creek as well as new plantings to stabilize the existing banks. Extension request for 25% of the costs past the deadline of March 2018 due to potential conflict with fish habitat.

properties.Name: Ensuring drinking water security, optimization and emergency response
properties.Description:
Project Description:There are increasing occurrences in Nunavut of water sources, storage facilities and treatment systems being compromised or threatened. This project will provide a range of proactive and emergency response capacity-building measures to prevent or mitigate against the drinking water insecurity in Nunavut communities. In one component of the project, a reverse osmosis system will be modified to meet the emergency needs of a greater number of communities. Due to its size, this previously purchased system could not be transported to 13 communities resulting in one third of all Nunavumiut not having reliable access to an alternative water treatment process. This unit will be separated into two sections and modified into a package that can be easily transported to all communities to address emergency water treatment needs. The second component of the project will provide supports to communities in meeting increasingly stringent potable water guidelines developed in southern Canada relying on advanced technologies that have limited or unattainable applications within Nunavut. Local capacity will be improved to optimize the water treatment plant operations to reflect unique water treatment challenges and to improve responsiveness to seasonal variables unique to arctic environments.

During the design phase the addition of sheet piling over earthen berm, additional channels to accommodate future phosphorus upgrades, overland flows are recommended. properties.Name: Fire hydrant replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replace broken hydrant and purchase spare hydrants for community. Broken hydrants are susceptible to infiltration and can compromises the water system. Off-reserve benefits are more secure and safe drinking water supply leading to reduced burden to provincial health care system
Construction Start Date:2017-03-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-01

properties.Name: Water Infrastructure Upgrades in Chesterfield Inlet, Arviat and Sanikiluaq
properties.Description:
Project Description:The water systems in Chesterfield Inlet, Arviat and Sanikiluaq do not have the capacity to meet the needs of the community and/or the treatment levels do not meet current health or regulatory standards. The project will improve the water distribution process, expand water storage capacity and improve the level of treatment to meet current regulatory standards. In Chesterfield Inlet, the improvements include a new water treatment plant, a treated water storage tank, a new transmission pipe line from the raw water source to the reservoir and associated equipment, as well as the demolishing of the old water treatment plant and associated infrastructure. In Arviat, the improvements include gravity filtration, chlorination and UV treatment, expanding the water reservoir and the construction of two truckfill arms to reduce distribution time and in Sanikiluaq, a water storage tank will be installed to improve the level of treatment to meet current regulatory standards.
Construction Start Date:2018-06-01
Construction End Date:2020-08-31

properties.Name: Port Alice Water Tank Replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project works will include: - Installation of water tank, base, and piping; - Electrical connections; and, - Demolition and disposal of old tank.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-19
Construction End Date:2018-02-28

properties.Name: Water Pollution Control Plant- Disinfection (Ecoli) and Preliminary Treatment (Headworks) Upgrades
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Town's goal of this project is to provide for a proactive remediation to an aging facility that was originally built in 1975, in response to more stringent effluent regulatory requirements and to provide for ongoing problems during spring freshet and storm events at the Cochrane Water Pollution Control Plant (WPCP). Specifically, install either UV or chemical injection for effluent disinfection and reconfigure the headworks to allow operations to accommodate higher flows during spring freshet and storm events.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-10
Construction End Date:2018-11-30

properties.Name: Town of Huntsville Drainage Study
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Town of Huntsville is going to commission a Town wide Drainage Study to improve drainage and stormwater management within the community. The goal of the project will be to identify drainage and storm water management issues within the community and proactively plan to replace or enhance these 'hot spots'. This will allow for more effective planning and fewer issues in the future for all citizens of Huntsville
Construction Start Date:2017-09-15
Construction End Date:2018-02-05

properties.Name: Repair programmable logic controller (PLC) at the water treatment plant.  Located at the Elk Lake water Treatment plant, 4 First Street which serves 440 residents and 160 service connections.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Repairs to programmable logic controller (PLC) due to recent PLC program failure. The PLC is now running on a temporary system. Objective: To replace the old out of commission PLC which runs the high lift side of the water plant. Scope: To purchase the hardware, design and create the program, install at the plant, satisfy regulators, test the new system and provide training on the new system to the staff. Output: A fully functioning PLC at the water plant.
Construction Start Date:2016-06-24
Construction End Date:2016-12-13

properties.Name: Pump house   Treatment Plant  Flow meter
properties.Description:
Project Description:"The existing flow meter was stuck by lightning, replaced , hit by lightning, repaired and hit by lightning a third time. It is believed that it is because it was hard wired thus conducted the electricity causing the unit to stop working. The information will be transmitted through radio frequency as to prevent this from happening in the future. The scope of the project was to replace the flow meter that became non-operational and could not be repaired. The line was used to also measure the primary disinfections that was hard wired to communicate with the PCL. After the flow meter was replaced, the line was hit by lightning and rendered the communication inoperable. This happened twice. The solution was to use radio communication between the flow meter and PCL to ensure that the communication is not disrupted. The flow meters analog output will be through radio which transmits to a receiver located at the water plant, that outputs a value to the PLC. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Changes issued an order to have this completed. IO NOTE: This is a newly proposed project. There will be an increase in Federal Funding of $8,000 to be reallocated from COB-002."
Construction Start Date:2018-02-15
Construction End Date:2018-03-15

properties.Name: Water main replacement on Thornton Rd. from Champlain Ave. to 300 m North, Whitby
properties.Description:
Project Description:"This project will be replacing 0.3 km of old ductile iron water main with new Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) water main. The water main services a commercial/industrial area of The Town Whitby and is looped as part of the ultimate distribution system to provide system security and improved water quality. Due to delays in developing the agreement and consequent local priority changes, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: This is a newly proposed project. This will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $185,000 to be reallocated from DUR-001 and DUR-012."
Construction Start Date:2018-03-05
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Improve Freeze protection on water main
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replace six heat trace controllers. Completion of this project is critical to the safe/efficient supply of water to the community, thus reducing the potential for additional pressure on the province's health care system
Construction Start Date:2018-07-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Replace Existing Programmable Logic Controller and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition computer (SCADA) system due to Obsolete and Impending Failure
properties.Description:
Project Description:Low Lift Station - replace the obsolete Allen Bradley Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) and HMI system Hardware (replacement, re-programming, rewiring); and Water Treatment Plant - replace the obsolete Allen Bradley PLC system hardware (replacement, backup, re-programming, rewiring, remote access device) Will Ensure reliable source of Potable water for community and thus will reduce water demands for the adjacent Municipalities
Construction Start Date:2017-11-30
Construction End Date:2018-03-09

properties.Name: Low lift pump repair
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will rebuild/replace the low lift pump to have the capacity to restore service in an emergency such as pump failure in order to continue to service the community. Completion of this project is critical to the safe/ efficient supply of water to the community, thus reducing potential impact on the Province's health system.

properties.Name: Design and Contract Administration Water Quality Improvements - Extension of Little Lake Road Watermain
properties.Description:
Project Description:Design and contract administration for the Little Lake Road Watermain extension to provide a looped water distribution system to improve water quality as a result of the existing dead end line. This will require the installation of approximately 200m of 150 mm diameter polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe. The new line will connect to the existing distribution line creating continued water circulation and improve the water quality of stagnant water and reducing maintenance needs of the system. Completion of this project will ensure that safe reliable drinking water is available and reduce the potential for additional pressure on the province's health care. Project does not include capital works.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-01
Construction End Date:2017-06-01

properties.Name: Improve  operations  with an asset management  program
properties.Description:
Project Description:Creating an up to date asset management program will increase operators' awareness of regular duties and increase monitoring of all operators and materials and supplies. Operations and maintenance of water systems requires regular inspection and maintenance of the daily, weekly, monthly and yearly maintenance items of the water plant and water distribution system. This program will also assist with monitoring budgets. Completion of this project will ensure that safe reliable drinking water is available and will have the off-reserve benefit of reducing the potential for additional pressure on the First Nations' health care demands on the provincial system.
Construction Start Date:2017-12-14
Construction End Date:2018-12-21

properties.Name: Sewage Lift System 1 - Replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:Sewage Lift station (Asset# 400400-03 CC#B2 2.9) - Replacement and reconditioning of entire system due to severe corrosion, the entire system in need of replacement or reconditioning. Ensure proper coatings are included in the design. Successful completion of this project will ensure that untreated wastewater does not enter the environment and negatively impact surrounding communities.

The water main will service 100 households and looped as part of the ultimate distribution system to provide system security and improved water quality. This will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $650,000 to be reallocated from DUR-012."

properties.Name: Cathode Study and Replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:"This project involves a study to determine the efficacy of a cathodic protection plan for the village of Morrisburg and the Morrisburg/Iroquois transmission main and to develop an implementation plan for the installation of cathodic protection.  Also included in this project will be the implementation of the plan (up to the allocated budget) by installing various cathodic protection nodes and anode banks at the most critical or effective areas in the distribution system, with the ultimate outcome to significantly reduce corrosion of the existing ductile iron water mains and the associated water main breaks due to corrosion. Due to delays in developing the agreement and changes to local priorities, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: This is a newly proposed project. This will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $37,500 to be reallocated from MSD-003."
Construction Start Date:2018-05-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-01

properties.Name: Sewer Christopher's Cove
properties.Description:
Project Description:1) Connect properties of the South side of route 440 to a municipal collection system. 2) New sanitary bypass main. 3) Upgrade storm main 4) Reinstate road/lawn/driveways/parking lots
Construction Start Date:2017-09-25
Construction End Date:2018-11-20

properties.Name: Low impact development study, pilot projects (construction) and water quality monitoring for the Fletcher's Creek Sustainable Retrofit Neighbourhood (incl. storm sewer design for an untreated roadway)
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Revised project *** See Keynotes for previous information Sustainable Neighbourhood Retrofit Action Plans (SNAP) were developed by the conservation authorities and a neighbourhood within Fletcher's creek was identified as having significant potential for improving stormwater management. This project will create the design drawings for a linear treatment for stormwater along Haggart Ave and allow for the design and construction of a school/community installation project. Monitoring equipment will be installed to establish baseline conditions and assess the impacts of projects on stormwater. SNAP implementation plans, policies, and operations and maintenance plans (for use on a city-wide basis) will be developed. Redside Dace habitat improvements may also be realized , which is identified as a Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry priority. The $650,000 decrease in total project cost (i.e. $325,000 in federal CWWF funding) reflects the removal of the construction of roadworks from the project scope (Haggart Ave). Public Works has identified that the resurfacing of the road will be delayed due to adjacent construction activities. Construction of a pilot project, monitoring and design of the linear low impact development stormwater treatment for Haggart Ave will proceed as planned. Due to delays Due to delays in the development of the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delay in procurement, and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-02
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Sanitary Forcemain and Watermain Replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:Sanitary forcemain and watermain replacement along Lawfield Drive, Mohawk Street, Miramichi Road, and saint john Ave. This project includes related road work necessary to complete the project.

Construction End Date:2017-11-30

properties.Name: Replacement of Sanitary Sewer and Construction Storm Water Sewer - 12th Street.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replace sanitary sewer and build storm water sewer on 12th Street. The project includes related roadwork required to finish the project.

properties.Description:
Project Description:Analyze scenarios for mitigating town flooding by Le Goulet Lake. Project includes design, drawings and specifications.

properties.Name: New Lagoon Evaporation Cell
properties.Description:
Project Description:The existing undersized lagoon evaporation cell system does not meet environmental regulatory requirements, and will be upgraded by adding a new cell and lift station. Construct a lagoon evaporation cell, lift station, force main, and all associated works. The new works are designed to serve 1100 persons.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-26
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Anthony Road, Glam Road and Boyd Avenue Water Sewer Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will provide new water, sewer and road upgrading in the Glam Road, Anthony's Road and Boyd Avenue area of Clarke's Beach for 38 residences to bring this area up to standards of the adjacent area. It will replace the existing water and septic systems by upgrading the aging 50mm water supply line and replacing the currently used septic system with a sewer system. This project will also include the installation of a new 870m-50mm HDPE waterline on Conception Bay Highway and Riverview Avenue at 1.8m minimum bury to replace the existing 38mm waterline which ran through the Clarkes Pond and has since deteriorated. It is now removed and a temporary 25mm waterline is connected, above ground, to provide temporary water service to 25 homes and businesses.

Construction End Date:2017-12-15

properties.Name: Brideau Avenue - Water, Sanitary and Storm Systems Renewal
properties.Description:
Project Description:Renewal of watermains, sanitary sewer mains, and storm sewer along Brideau Avenue. This project includes related road work necessary to complete the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-05
Construction End Date:2018-07-31

properties.Name: Rossini area relining of both Storm and Sanitary pipes which run under the high school
properties.Description:
Project Description:Relining of storm and sanitary lines which run under a high school to ensure structural integrity. This line provides service to 106 residents in the area as well as the high school. If lines failed and required reconstruction it would impact the high school structure which sits above it. Open cut and pipe bursting are not viable options in this situation. Total pipe being relined is 160m for sanitary (vitrified clay) and 160m for storm (concrete)
Construction Start Date:2017-05-01
Construction End Date:2019-06-30

properties.Name: Improve water quality at the dead end on McIntyre Street by installing flushing capacity
properties.Description:
Project Description:Currently we cannot flush to correct water quality issues/concerns from consumers. This project will construct a fire hydrant to allow flushing at the dead end on McIntyre Street. This will improve water quality.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-01
