Construction End Date:2018-08-30

properties.Name: Construction of a 300-mm Water Main on Mount Pleasant Road
properties.Description:
Project Description:Construction of a 2.9km, 300-mm water main on Mount Pleasant Road from the Palgrave Reservoir to McGuire Trail to improve security of supply and water quality in the Palgrave water supply system by creating a looped system.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-31
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Turtle Pond Stormwater Management Pond Sediment Removal and Clean Out
properties.Description:
Project Description:An assessment was completed in 2015 to assess various City owned wet pond stormwater management facilities. The 2003 Stormwater Management Planning and Design Manual indicates that sediment accumulation reduces the permanent pool volume and the removal efficiency of suspended solids (SS). The SWMP indicates that when the designed removal efficiency of the suspended solids is reduced by 5% or greater, a clean out of the SWM facility is needed by removing the deposited sediment from the permanent pool. This will ensure that the stormwater (SWM) facility remains functional meeting the original design objectives. A 5% reduction in removal efficiency is equivalent to 30% (+/-) reduction in permanent pool volume. Through the 2015 assessment project, this particular wet pond was determined to be in need of a cleanout within a short-term timeframe (1-5 years). The Northridge Estates Phase II stormwater management wet pond was constructed in 1997 and is located within Turtle Pond Park in the Citys north end. The wet pond services primarily residential land uses and is comprised of a forebay pool and main cell pool. This project will primarily consist of the removal of 3026 cubic metres of sediment (via drain and excavate), but will also include other remedial needs such as signage repair and replacement, repair or replacement of equalization pipe and repair eroded berm between forebay and main bay. All remedial needs have been identified in the 2015 assessment. The preliminary estimated cost for this project includes estimates for average transportation and tipping fees to dispose the sediment at an approved receiving facility. The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Watermain relining on Clairton Place
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "The project includes the relining of approximately 400 metres of water main along Clairton Place in the Community of Amherstview, as well as the replacement of valves and fire hydrants associated with the system. The water main for this section of the Amherstview drinking water system includes 150mm and 250mm cast iron pipes that were installed in 1967. These lines service approximately 30 households, several of which have complained about coloured water, indicating a need for this part of the system to be rehabilitated. This project is a local priority. The availability of CWWF funding will allow for this project to proceed. This project was completed as part of a larger relining program run by the Township. This contributed to lower design and construction costs, since consultants and contractor costs were divided amongst several streets. Contract administration was also completed in-house, making these costs ineligible. Expanded scope: - required to relocate isolation valve from wet well to new valve chamber immediately adjacent to the wet well due to the restricted space in the existing wet well - added LED lights to the wet well and valve chamber - entrance hatch to the new valve chamber was a special order aluminum hatch for ease of ingress and egress - MBQ did not decommission the existing 100mm force main. It will be utilized as a bypass in the event repairs are required at the station. This required the addition of one (1) 100mm valve and one (1) 150mm valve. IO NOTE: Due to the decreased costs, despite having completed additional work, there is a decrease in Federal Funding of $49,819.50 which will be reallocated to LOY-004."
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-01

properties.Name: Renewal of water pipes
properties.Description:
Project Description:Pipe renewal works aimed at maintaining water services for citizens for 4 stretches of road and totaling 0.233 km.
Construction Start Date:2018-05-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Replacement of the Existing Standby Generator at Buckhorn Lake Estates
properties.Description:
Project Description:The existing standby generator is considered a high risk source of contamination in the municipal drinking water well head protection area due to its proximity to the existing well. The existing generator uses diesel fuel the replacement generator will be with a propane fuel source which will eliminate the risk of a fuel spill from the generator at the well house.
Construction Start Date:2018-02-20
Construction End Date:2018-03-03

properties.Name: Structural Relining  (Cure in Place) of Sanitary Sewers at 4 locations
properties.Description:
Project Description:This Relining project (Cure in Place) is expected to rehabilitate approximately 2200 m of pipe sizes of 200/250mm and in various locations. The lining will prevent further deterioration of the host pipe and avoid any further collapses or blockages. The smoother interior lining would reduce friction factors and allow for better operation and easier cleaning and maintenance. In addition ground infiltration is reduced at these locations. This rehabilitation will be done with trenchless technology to minimize disturbance to the surrounding area and minimize restoration costs. This project involves the following streets - Pitt Street, Ross Street, Highway #17, and Duke Street. This kind of work is becoming cost prohibitive to the City unless the City puts out larger contracts as the mobilization to service Dryden is expensive. Dependent on the area these repairs could affect up to 100 homes and prevent sewer backup.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-01
Construction End Date:2017-12-29

properties.Name: Seegmiller Avenue Sanitary Sewer Relining
properties.Description:
Project Description:Relining of 200 mm diameter concrete sanitary pipe utilizing cured-in place pipe no dig technology. The current concrete pipe installed in the 1960's is exhibiting interior spalling and loss of interior surface as observed in the most recent CCTV inspections. The adjoining watermain is in good condition making this project an excellent choice for rehabilitation. This rehabilitation will avoid open cut trenching that will minimize the disruption to approximately 18 residential homes along the length of pipe being rehabilitated.
Construction Start Date:2018-02-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Upgrade to the Town of Greater Napanee Wastewater Pollution Control Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Water Pollution Control Plant (WPCP) requires an increase in rated capacity in order to handle both the normal and wet weather flows. An upgrade will greatly reduce the risk of effluent bypasses into the Napanee River, which is regularly used by the community and for tourism purposes. The treatment will be upgraded to comply with more stringent effluent criteria proposed by the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change (MOECC) and the Bay of Quinte Remedial Action Plan (BQRAP). Once the WPCP is expanded and upgraded, it will have sufficient capacity to handle the growing wastewater demand in sustainable fashion. The increased plant capacity will also allow for more economic development within the community. The Town of Greater Napanee has recently turned away interested proposals for further industrial and commercial development due to treatment constraints.
Construction Start Date:2018-03-19
Construction End Date:2018-08-31

properties.Name: Billings Bridge Drinking Water Pump Station Diesel System Upgrade
properties.Description:
Project Description:Design and build a new code compliant diesel system within the Annex building. Modifications required include a fire proof room (complete with heating, electrical, and ventilation systems) to house the storage tank and act as containment, a cooling system for the return fuel, reconfiguration of the existing cooling water piping. The system is to have a 9000L storage tank and a 750L day tank. An extension beyond March 31, 2018 is requested due to ongoing real-estate negotiations with the NCC (regarding a Federal Land Use Agreement) and potential to encounter contaminated soils.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-17
Construction End Date:2018-07-15

properties.Name: Water Street Culvert Replacement and Creek Enhancement
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project entails the rehabilitation of approximately 30m of an existing concrete and creosote box culvert across Water Street. This outlet to Summerside's east end drainage area (along one of our major collector roadways) may affect 6000-7000 residents and 7000 vehicles per day traveling the collector street to western PEI's busies port. Preventing the contamination of Bedeque Bay's 6 million dollar shellfish industry from wash outs of the structures impacted by climate change. This project involves the replacement of an existing concrete and creosote box culvert (which is at the end of its life span). Replacement of the storm sewer structure and the roadway will be included in this project.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2017-12-31

properties.Name: East Royalty Gravity to CPCP Upgrade
properties.Description:
Project Description:The gravity sewer system, for an approximate distance of 3.0km, taking flows from East Royalty to Charlottetown Pollution Control Plant will be upgraded to handle the increased flows.
Construction Start Date:2018-03-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-01

properties.Name: Sewage Clarifier Rehabilitation, tank rake-paddle installation (Cat Lake Road)
properties.Description:
Project Description:The scope of the project includes first cleaning out and rehabilitating the sewage clarifier tank and then installing rake paddles, a new motor and bearings. This involves hiring a hydrovac truck and operator from Thunder Bay (540 km away) to pump out the tank so we can clean it out to expose problems, and inspect the pumps and aerator; then install rake paddles, a motor and bearings. Our objective is to remove the anaerobic sludge mass from the bottom of the tank and upgrade the agitation equipment to facilitate complete aerobic processing of the sewage. The resultant outcome of this project will be efficient, expedition and complete sewage processing.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-02
Construction End Date:2017-11-10

properties.Name: Storm Sewer Network Study-Old Milton Area
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will evaluate the existing storm sewer infrastructure, identify deficiencies, make recommendations and develop a program for the maintenance, rehabilitation and  replacement of the storm sewer infrastructure  in Milton bounded by Thompson Road, Bronte Street,  Derry Road and Steeles Avenue. Although this study will not directly increase the capacity or life span of an asset, this data will support and be integrated into a program that will increase the life span of the storm sewer network.  Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-18
Construction End Date:2018-09-01

properties.Name: Rehabilitation of Well # 3 located on 6th Street including New Casing and pump
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Well # 3 has been in operation since 1989 and it is our main well for the town of Earlton located in the Township of Armstrong. It pumps on average 9 litres of water per second. The pump ohms are tested once a year every year and these yearly tests are showing a steady decline in pump power. The loss of this well for any amount of time would be very stressful on our two other wells which can only produce 3 litres of water per second each and they would have to be pumping constantly to keep up with the town's water demand. For those reasons we would like to replace the casing and pump before complete failure. We had a firm quote for this project and the job simply did not require the amount of work that was quoted for. IO NOTE: There is a decrease in the amount of work required to complete the job. As a result, there is a decrease in Federal Funding of $763 to be reallocated to ARMS-004."
Construction Start Date:2017-10-10
Construction End Date:2017-10-30

properties.Name: Repairs and upgrades to distribution system valves, replace all stems and valves in distribution system.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replace existing stems and valves in distribution system with upgraded stems and valves with freeze protection. Off-reserve benefits include more secure and safe drinking water, reducing the burden to provincial health care system.
Construction Start Date:2018-08-01
Construction End Date:2020-03-31

properties.Name: Upgrades to the Colchester South Lagoons and Pump Station including Aerator, MCC Panels and Sewage Pumps
properties.Description:
Project Description:I) Existing surface aerators are highly inefficient in terms of process and energy. Installation of 4 high efficient surface aerators will replace the old and aging aerators and result in better treatment process, energy savings and reduce the carbon footprint. ii) Replace the aging Motor Control Center (MCC) Panels with new diesel transfer switch, pump and aerator panels. This will result in more reliable and efficient supply in the system and, reduce energy and carbon footprint. Aging MCC panels are also becoming a major health & safety risk. The diesel generator transfer switch will also be replaced. Due to age, it is becoming unreliable. iii) The main raw pumps for the collection system which pump to the Colchester Lagoon are aged. Due to age, the raw pumps will be replaced with 2 new high efficient pumps which include Variable Frequency Drives. This will result in a more reliable and efficient supply in the system with less breakdown, reduce energy and the carbon footprint. All piping and valving will also be replaced since it is quickly deteriorating due to age and constantly being in a hazardous environment. This will also result in a more reliable and efficient supply in the system with less chance of breakdown. A new raw flow meter will also be installed to assist with operations and compliance. Engineering services will have to be utilized
Construction Start Date:2017-08-30
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: New Wastewater Treatment System
properties.Description:
Project Description:Objective: Build a new wastewater system that meets provincial regulations. Scope: Plan, design and construct new lagoon system including appx single cell with advanced treatment facility, and all associated works. Output: New lagoon wastewater treatment system including advanced treatment.
Construction Start Date:2018-05-15
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Community Wide Stormwater Improvement
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project entails the removal of the current storm-water culvert systems and the installation of new culverts in the identical locations using existing/original granular backfill materials. All culverts for this project are located within the existing developed area of the community and do not alter the existing drainage system patterns. Existing/adjacent community storm-water drainage ditches will be improved upon by the removal of overgrowth plant materials & all obstructions ensuring that the storm-water levels will flow freely and not pond or accumulate, thereby negating any potential environmental impacts on the receiving area of Sandy Lake.
Construction Start Date:2018-06-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Feasibility study and detailed design for optimizing seasonal lagoons discharge.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Feasibility study to determine if gravity discharge of the lagoons is possible or if installing bigger pumps is the best solution in order to be able to discharge seasonally. Project will proceed to complete design solution as per the recommendations from the feasibility study. At this time, the lagoons are not being discharged as per regulations. Successful completion of this project will ensure that untreated wastewater does not enter the environment and negatively impact surrounding communities.
Construction Start Date:2018-03-01
Construction End Date:2018-04-30

properties.Name: Sewer Collection System Rehabilitation Addressing High Infiltration Rates
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will rehabilitate and redesign of High Point Stormwater Pond. High Point pond is currently a quantity pond and we intend to redesign as a quality/quantity pond. This will bring the pond up to modern standards. The original design of the pond resulted in a quantity facility, it stored water and released it slowly to lower the peak affect of storm water runoff. The proposed pond will be converted to a quality/quantity pond so it will serve two functions - 1. Quantity and 2. Quality where a forebay is constructed in order catch sediment before discharging downstream. This change will bring the pond up to modern standards. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-12
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: Screw pump upgrades for the Raw Sewage Lift Station at Stratford Water Pollution Control Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:The raw sewage lift station at the Water Pollution Control Plant has three pumps to handle peak dry weather flows. The upgrade to the pumps will see variable frequency drives with new motors and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition updates added to each pump. This upgrade will increase pump efficiency and retain energy savings estimated at $23,025 per year.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-26
Construction End Date:2017-11-14

properties.Name: Replacement of Septic Systems
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replacement of failed Beausoleil First Nation septic systems at various locations within the community. Due to the age of the systems replacement is required as a health issue. Successful completion of this project will ensure that untreated wastewater does not enter the environment and negatively impact surrounding communities.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2017-12-30

properties.Name: Clearwater Septage Receiving Station Equalization Basin
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project works will include: - Construct a new 110m³ below ground concrete equalization basin; - Site preparation, excavation and restoration; and, - Installation of an odour control system on the new equalization basin.
Construction Start Date:2017-12-18
Construction End Date:2018-03-30

properties.Name: District of Port Hardy Reservoir Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:Project works will include: - demolition and replacement of the Town Reservoir; - construction of the new Beach Reservoir; - installation of a new chlorination station; - installation and replacement of over 3 km of watermains (250 mm, 300 mm, and 375 mm diameters); - related site and drainage works; - related civil, mechanical, electrical work and control systems.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-15
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Water distribution repairs - Replace seals and valves for 2 hydrants that are leaking badly in the distribution system
properties.Description:
Project Description:There are 2 hydrants that are in dire need of repairs because they are part of the distribution system and cause the distribution system to be less effective. Repair includes changing seal and valve. These are defective and are out of service for now and cause problem in the distribution system. To repair them, we will be required to turn off the water to a few street blocks, dig to replace a stuck/broken valve and repair/replace valve stems and casings, lift apart the ones that are dripping to investigate and replace defective seat/seal. A Boil Water Advisory will have to be issued during the course of the work, a series of bacti samples will be required to lift the boil water advisories afterwards. After completion of the work the operating authority (Ontario Clean Water Agency) will be able to conduct a thorough distribution system flush to help distributing a good water quality to all residences. The fire hydrants serve many purposes in the distribution system other than firefighting. They allow to do maintenance work such as conducting high flow flushing to help keep the distribution pipes clean, they are needed to flush out stagnant water at the dead ends in the distribution system. We need to have all fire hydrants and distribution valves working to conduct a swabbing program, swabs are inserted into the distribution system through hydrants and directed to a another hydrant by valving. This is why hydrants and valves are a very important and integral part of the distribution system.
Construction Start Date:2017-01-01
Construction End Date:2017-11-30

properties.Name: Wastewater Treatment System Rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:Objective: Enhance performance, rehabilitate and add to life of lagoon system. Scope: Plan, design and construct appx three rehabilitated lagoon berms, discharge valves, and two enlarged cells, and all associated works. Output: Rehabilitated lagoon system.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-07
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Replacement of Sanitary Main 2 - Man Hole 3A
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replacement of Man Hole 3A (MH3A) required due to major corrosion issues. Successful completion of this project will ensure that untreated wastewater does not enter the environment and negatively impact surrounding communities.
Construction Start Date:2017-01-03
Construction End Date:2017-04-05

properties.Name: Procurement of Equipment for Water Treatment Plant Operations
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will involve the detailed identification and procurement of necessary operational equipment including, more efficient chlorination pumps, a new storage trailer for necessary equipment. The storage trailer would be mobile but would remain at the water treatment plant as a permanent fixture for use exclusively by the Water Treatment Staff for additional storage of water treatment plan items (e.g. health and safety equipment including safety masks, etc.). Without adequate funding the community will continue to operate the Water Treatment plant without the necessary operational and safety equipment which puts our operator and the system at risk. This project will eliminate health and safety issues for the community and the province.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Replacing or adding to the Filter Media inside the filter media tanks that provides filtration of particles present in the inflowing water from the treatment cycle after flocculation.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Inspect and replacing or top up the Filter Media inside the filter media tanks that provides filtration of particles present in the inflowing water from the treatment cycle after flocculation. The efficient and safe operation of the filtration system will ensure that no additional health burden is placed on the Province due to drinking water issues
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-30

properties.Name: Peat Moss System Rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:Maintain and repair peat moss septic treatment systems for 3-4 houses. Project will improve wastewater treatment and reduce contamination to receiving water bodies off reserve.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-30

properties.Name: Restoration of stormdrain outfall
properties.Description:
Project Description:The replacement of the existing deteriorated 1 meter diameter, 18 meter long corrugated culvert with a new .5 meter diameter, 18 meter long corrugated culvert. The existing culvert is failing with signs of holes which is located on Willison Service Road. This culvert location on Willison Service Road is a part of our trucking haul route. This project will prevent local flooding and improve overall management of the catchment area, thus benefiting neighboring communities.
Construction Start Date:2018-03-26
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: Water Service Replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Replacement of water services in the town of Georgina that have frozen previously or have been identified as a leaking distribution line and requires rehabilitation to address water loss. Due to delays in developing the agreement and changes in local priorities, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: This is a newly proposed project. There will be an increase of $62,500 in Federal Funding to be reallocated from GEO-001."
Construction Start Date:2018-05-15
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Water Treatment Plant Communication Controls Upgrade
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project includes the installation of a new radio tower within the community to allow for the proper communication protocols to occur from the water tower to the water treatment plant. Currently, the community does not have a proper way to report and collect data from the water tower and the water treatment plant, and are unable to receive proper notification in the event of an occurrence or emergency. The radio tower will help eliminate the risk of an emergency as well as health and safety risks by providing proper communication protocols. In turn, this will help promote and maintain the health and safety of the community, lowering the risk of members being exposed to an unpotable water supply. This will reduce the potential for community members to seek medical care, thus reducing the strain on the provinces health care systems.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Chippewas of Kettle and Stony Point Water Treatment Plant and Distribution Capital Plan
properties.Description:
Project Description:Design and planning for upgrades to the water treatment plant and distribution system to support federal regulatory requirements, capacity demand for growth and development and benefit of elevated storage. Develop an inventory of key assets and compare their condition and age to typical life expectancy values and prepare a schedule for repair and replacement including probable costs based on a 10 year plan. Examine existing water treatment plant capacity against demand giving consideration to growth and demand, development, disinfection considerations and the benefit of an elevated storage. Examine options to improve the water intake with goal of improving water quality and reducing operational issues. Off reserve benefits - The Chippewas of Kettle and Stony Point First Nation water support system is generated by Lake Huron part of the Great Lakes, the plan will provide short and long term solutions that attribute to protection of the Great Lakes water ways and environment. Safer long term water operations will reduce the burden on the provincial health care system.
Construction Start Date:2018-04-16
Construction End Date:2018-12-16

properties.Name: Culvert Replacement Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:Culvert replacement to replace 40-year-old culvert on Kokomis Road. Off-reserve benefit are better drainage and increased environmental protection of the Bonnechere River, plus less risk of sediment and run-off into the Bonnechere River.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-01
Construction End Date:2017-12-01

properties.Name: Water main replacement on Laval Street from Hillside Ave. to Laval Crt., Oshawa
properties.Description:
Project Description:"This project will be replacing 0.4 km of old cast iron water main with new Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) water main. The water main services 20 households, a school and is looped as part of the ultimate distribution system to provide system security and improved water quality. Due to delays in developing the agreement and consequent local priority changes, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: This is a newly proposed project. This will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $277,320 to be reallocated from DUR-012."
Construction Start Date:2018-03-05
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: MaCourtice SWM Pond Rehabilitation and Sediment Cleanout including Removal of approximately 110m3 of sediment and installation of an Oil Grit Separator unit
properties.Description:
Project Description:"NEW PROJECT: The MaCourtice Storm Water Management Pond is a rehabilitation, retrofit and sediment cleanout project including removal of approximately 110 m3 of sediment and installation of an Oil Grit Separator unit. The project was identified in the SWMFMG (Stormwater Management Facility Maintenance Guidance) report as a priority for retrofit. The Storm Water Management pond is located in Courtice, Ontario draining to Black Creek. The estimated cost for cleanout of the project is $110,000 which exceeds the annual funding amount ($90,000) and would not proceed in 2017/2018 without special funding from the Clean Water and Wastewater Fund (CWWF). The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset. Due to delays in developing the agreement and consequent local priority changes, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: This is a new project to be submitted. This results in an increase in Federal Funding of $55,000 to be reallocated from CLA-003."
Construction Start Date:2018-01-01
Construction End Date:2018-09-15

properties.Name: Purchase and installation of remote chlorine analyzer(s) in the distribution system
properties.Description:
Project Description:Purchase and install remote chlorine analyzer(s) within distribution system. Off-reserve benefit is reduced burden to provincial health system by more secure potable water source.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-01

properties.Name: Mayo Water and Wastewater Line rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:Rehabilitation and replacement of various water and wastewater lines in Mayo. Resurfacing of affected roads and improvements to drainage.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-26
Construction End Date:2018-10-31

properties.Name: Hangar 8 Lift-Station Rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:The rehabilitation will involve the demolition of the existing lift station and the installation of a new lift station and valve chamber complete with updated control systems, upgraded sewer force main and gravity main lines and standby power generator. The new system will be accessible at the surface within a service building rather than in its current below ground confined space location.
Construction Start Date:2016-12-05
Construction End Date:2017-08-18

properties.Name: Alma springfield estates water and wastewater extension
properties.Description:
Project Description:Installation water and sanitary sewer (2,700m watermain and 2,500m sanitary sewer) as well as 3 grider pump systems. Wastewater to be treated at East River Environmental Control Centre in New Glasgow. 40 homes to be serviced.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-01
Construction End Date:2018-09-30

properties.Name: Water and Wastewater Upgrades
properties.Description:
Project Description:Lift station pump station upgrades, construction of new hydraulic tower and rehabilitation of water and wastewater lines in downtown Dawson
Construction Start Date:2018-05-01
Construction End Date:2018-11-30

properties.Name: Notley's Drive water and waste water system
properties.Description:
Project Description:Install 13 water and sewer services to Notley Drive.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-19
Construction End Date:2017-10-18

properties.Name: Design for a New Sanitary Trunk Sewer on Lakeshore Road West
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Detailed design for a new sanitary trunk sewer on Lakeshore Road West from Hurontario Street to the Richards Memorial Sewage Pumping Station to service intensification in Port Credit and to allow the Region to decommission the Front Street Sewage Pumping Station and the Ben Machree Sewage Pumping Station. Due to additional time required to complete preparatory work (i.e. EAs/soil testing/identifying utilities etc.), we are requesting an extension beyond March 31, 2018, to ensure successful completion of the project."
Construction Start Date:2016-09-08
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Study for New Water and Wastewater Servicing for the Belfountain Conservation Area
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Belfountain Conservation Area is experiencing an increasing number of visitors that has accelerated the need to improve water and wastewater services. The focus of the study will be on a new water supply and improved wastewater management to accommodate the growing demand.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Trenchless Sewer Rehabiliation at Multiple Locations
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Trenchless rehabilitation of 1,140m of sewer main and 90 private drain connections at various locations. The eligible costs are limited to public/municipal property and assets. The sewer directly services 120 households and a larger collection area. Extension Rationale: The contractors will finish the 2017 contract in spring 2018 and do the additional scope added to projects in fall 2018. The Dec 31 date was used to ensure there was enough to allow this to happen. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope. This will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $80,000.00."
Construction Start Date:2017-06-26
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Trenchless Water Rehabilitation at Multiple Locations
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** Trenchless rehabilitation of 1320 m of water main at various locations. The water main directly services 120 households. The eligible costs are limited to public/municipal property and assets. Extension Rationale: The contractors will finish the 2017 contract in spring 2018 and do the additional scope added to projects in fall 2018. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope. This will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $68,000.00.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: DeCew Falls Water Treatment Plant - Distribution feed upgrade (150 mm diameter Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) watermain 400 meters long) - located in the City of St. Catharines
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Tender Prices for this project were lower than anticipated, therefore, the project is under budget. The highest bid received was $466,162. The successful low bid was $240,748 and a change PO for an additional $81,317 was approved for a PRV chamber that was required to limit pressures in the municipal distribution system for a grand total of $322,000. This project will complete the construction of an independent water main (150 mm diameter Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) water main 400 meters long) and separation of the municipal services along DeCew Road from the in-plant service water system. This will increase the security of supply to nearby residents and improve the flexibility when work is required on the water treatment plant system. Total estimated project cost is $620,000 based on the projected 9 year capital forecast, of which $120 K is for engineering fees. The eligible costs under the CWWF are for the construction of the infrastructure. The DeCew Falls Water Treatment Plant located in St. Catharines provides treated water to approximately 181,500 people and has a rated capacity of 227,300 m³/day. The plant was constructed in three phases, starting with Plant 1 in 1925 and concluding with Plant 3 in 1974. This legacy construction approach has created an operational problem that affects the plants routine maintenance, and the nearby homes (DeCew Road). These homes are serviced directly from the Water Treatment Plant service water system. This causes complications when there is work required at the plant. IO NOTE: There is no decrease in scope. There is a reduction in the tender. There will be an decrease in Federal Funding of $56,334.00 to be reallocated to NIR-009."
Construction Start Date:2017-04-15
Construction End Date:2017-08-23

properties.Name: Design and Construction of Stormwater Quality Control Improvement at Existing Storm Sewer Outfall
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project includes implementing recommendations from the Town of Ajax (South of Hwy 401) Stormwater Management Retrofit Study and designing a solution which can be constructed and improve the quality of the stormwater being discharged into Duffins Creek. This includes the installation of a low-flow diversion within the existing storm sewer system to a proposed infiltration gallery. Due to regulatory requirements and/or permit delays, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.

properties.Name: Refurbish/Reline Water System Water Storage Standpipe on Henry Street to prevent detereoration of the cement walls due to water sepage and to extend the life of the standpipe
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** The objective of this project is to prevent the cement walls of the municipal water system's storage standpipe from deterioration and thereby extend the useful life of the standpipe. The scope of the project includes: emptying the standpipe of its water (approximately 2,200 cubic meters); sandblasting the interior (approximately 1,025 square meters); removing all the debris and cleaning the interior; recoating the interior with two coats of epoxy coating; and then refilling the standpipe with water. The desired output is to prevent water seepage though the concrete walls which would cause the walls to crack and deteriorate over time due to the fluctuating temperatures (freezing/thawing). This will extend the useful life of the standpipe and eliminate the need for costly repairs or even replacement of the standpipe. The higher project cost was because we use a different epoxy coating system that could be applied in colder weather (project never started until the end of November 2017 and was completed December 22, 2017). The original epoxy coating recommended by our OCWA engineers was a Carboline Coating system. During tender, contractors were unwilling to quote a fixed price contract since the quality of the interior surface of the tank was unknown. The Carboline System requires a relatively smooth surface. This meant that if the contractor found that surface repair was required, it would cost us more to complete the project. To avoid this, the winning bidder recommended that we use a Gemite Coating System that allow to coat the interior without significant repair and at no additional cost. Our engineers approved this change in scope to the project. The different epoxy coating system provides a better performance on rougher cement surfaces. IO NOTE: Due to the increase in scope, there is an increase in Federal Funding of $12,379.18 to be reallocated from MBA-002.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-15
Construction End Date:2018-01-12

properties.Name: Installation of Additional Flow and Pressure Monitoring for the Lake-Based Water Supply System
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Installation of additional flow and pressure monitoring equipment at various locations within the Region's lake-based water supply system to improve the Region's energy management system. The additional information will allow us to optimize the energy used for pumping the water and can identify operational issues that cause watermain breaks.This project will add flow meters in the transmission and sub-transmission system to help us further optimize how and when we move water throughout the system. Water demands within each pressure zone within the eastern and western regions are serviced by intermediate distribution pumping stations and reservoirs. High lift pumps within each pumping station provide flows to areas in the upper or northern zone. Low lift pumps provide water to the southern zone and supply water to the northern zone reservoir. To assist in the Monitoring and Operation of the overall South Peel water distribution system we intend to install 26 flow and pressure monitoring stations within the water distribution system, specifically in pressure zones 3, 4, 5 and 6. 10 locations have been identified for the proposed projects including Airport PS, Hanlan PS, Streetsville PS and North Brampton PS. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."

properties.Name: Pumphouse Road Water Treatment Plant Chlorination system replacement
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "The existing chlorination system has become outdated and can be unreliable. For the safety of the water produced, and quality assurance, and new chlorination system will be purchased and installed. The chlorination system replacement was slightly higher than expected because there were some added costs of a due to a slight change in scope of the project. The old chlorination system was to be replaced with similar type system. It was noted from the contractor that the chlorine residuals were determined through a pace to residual analyzer system which creates more fluctuations in the amount out chlorine that was needed to supply the water system. It was determined the better way to go would be to use a pace to flow system that would make it more stable and not fluctuate so much when the water left for the distribution system. The change in scope was due to the change from pace to residual to pace to flow which required they run wiring to the flow meters to achieve this goal. The revised scope improves system operation and provides greater water quality assurance to the community. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, resulting in an increase in Federal Funding of $1,500 to be reallocated from COB-002."

These projects are listed as medium or high priority for replacement. Upgrades are also needed on the Natural gas unit heater at the water treatment plant, as well as the need for a replacement mage flow meter well. Project Description:The project will involve a major cleaning and repainting of the Mildmay Water tower to ensure the long term operations of the water tower are not affected. As the only water tower in Village of Mildmay, this work is required to ensure that the Village has safe reliable drinking water. The Tower also provides water pressure to ensure that there are adequate fire flows within the Village. If this work is not undertaken, the corrosion will continue to get worse and spread at an increased rate. This work needs to be undertaken immediately to stop the spread of the corrosion. If it is not stopped it will lead to most costly repairs and downtime for repairs which will result in the approximately 1100 residents not having access to drinking water or fire protection. The operational improvements will improve access and security to better protect the village's potable water supply. Due to weather-sensitive work that must be completed outside of winter months, we are requesting an extension beyond March 31, 2018, to ensure successful completion of the project.

properties.Name: Cobden Drinking Water System Emergency Diesel Generator Upgrade Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will replace the undersized, aging stationary emergency diesel generator set with a new suitably sized diesel generator set to be stationary situated outside of the water plant in its own enclosure with a double walled fuel tank. The Cobden Water Plant supplies potable water to roughly 980 users within the Village of Cobden. In 2008 the Water Plant underwent a major upgrade but the project neglected to replace the undersized stationary diesel gen set. The existing undersized diesel emergency generator set at the Cobden Water Plant has resulted in the inability to run the back-wash process while operating high lift and low lift pumps (all new equipment introduced during the 2008 upgrades). In the event of an extended power outage, there is only a short time to supply water to the system until the filter need to initiate a backwash on loss of head, time and turbidity. The inability to backwash the filter will result in no further treated water entering the clearwell as elevated levels of filter turbidity will lock out the system. Both the clearwell and the elevated tower will become depleted in a short time if demand is high. Backwashing of the filter is a requirement of the treatment process and when treating surface water, the elevated level of organics in the source water demands continuous backwashing. The locking out of the system as a result of filter turbidity levels is a requirement of Provincial Legislation (O. Reg. 170 of the Safe Drinking Water Act). Elevated turbidity in source water will harbor unwanted bacteria in populations that the disinfection process may miss or be ineffective. If the Plant cannot backwash as required, the Plant will not produce clean, safe drinking water to replenish the clearwell or elevated tower via the high lift pumps.
Construction Start Date:2018-06-01
Construction End Date:2018-08-31

properties.Name: Clarifier Design &  Environmental Assessment - Wastewater Plant Improvements
properties.Description:
Project Description:***Modified project - See notes for original information*** "Design, Environmental Assessment and Engineering for addition of clarifier at wastewater treatment plant (WWTP). Growth is expected in the municipality. We want to be prepared for the expansion of the plant. An Environmental Assessment is required by the Ministry of Environment prior to the construction of a third clarifier. The work is considered necessary due to Fisheries Act Regulation. The detailed design of a third Final Clarifier to improve the WWTP's ability to treat existing loadings and increase redundancy for this critical unit process. To construct a 3rd Clarifier, it will be necessary to relocate both the WWTP's access road and the WWTP water supply. Relocation of the access road also causes the need to replace existing WWTP Security Fencing. Because of the nature of this work (i.e. general site works construction), it would be advantageous to have it completed before the Clarifier Construction which is mostly a structural project. The investigations of WWTP capacity has also identified that wastewater currently by-passes the WWTP inlet. The result is that a portion of the WWTP inflow on some days is not measured, recorded and accounted for when assessing and managing the plant loads. Installation of a flow meter on the return line from the Peak Flow Storage Lagoon would allow this wastewater stream to be quantified which will benefit both current assessments and long-term operations. A 3rd Clarifier will require a scum pump similar to those on the existing clarifiers. Although the best approach is still subject to detailed design, there will also be long-term value in increasing the Return Activated Sludge (RAS) pumping capacity. Pre-selecting and pre-purchasing a 4th RAS pump or a larger replacement for the existing pumps will increase the functionality of the new Clarifier. Due to delays in developing agreement and project complexity, extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required
Construction Start Date:2016-09-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Replacement of Spent Granular Activated Carbon Filter Media at Water Treatment Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Town of Smiths Falls currently owns and operates a Class IV high rate dissolved air flotation (AquaDAF) surface water treatment plant (WTP) with a design capacity of 14,000m3/day. Raw water for the treatment process is drawn from the Rideau River. The final step in removing particles from the drinking water treatment process is accomplished through filtration. Presently, there are three deep bed dual media gravity filters located at the WTP. Each filter consists of a layer of Granular Activated Carbon (GAC) and sand. The purpose of the GAC is to absorb organic compounds, taste and odor compounds and synthetic organic chemicals. The GAC materials were installed at the plant in 2009 with the construction of the new facility. Over time, the effectiveness of GAC materials are reduced and the product needs to be changed out. The GAC media at the water plant has been independently tested and the materials are recommended for replacement in the Asset Management Plan in 2018. Replacement of filter media is expected to improve filter performance, increase organics removals and improve the Towns multi barrier approach to manage levels of Trihalomethanes (THM) in treated drinking water.

properties.Name: Stormwater Management Pond# PD33-03 Sediment Management
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will result in the removal and disposal of 1,600 m3 of sediment from the stormwater pond, and includes cleaning of outlets and restoration of the disturbed area. Majority of the Towns storm water ponds had been constructed with permanent storage volume (wet ponds). The purpose of the permanent storage volume in a pond is to allow suspended solids (sediment) from the runoff to settle down in the pond bottom and release the treated water to the creek. Over the time, pond will accumulate sediment which will reduce the permanent storage, impacting the sediment removal efficiency of the pond drastically, resulting untreated water released to the Creek. Realising a need for a pond clean out, Town of Whitby conducted a ponds need study in 2011 to evacuate the pond permanent storage capacity and learned majority of the ponds require cleanout as bathymetric survey revealed fair amount of sediment accumulated in the ponds. Under this project accumulated sediment in the pond will be removed allowing required permanent storage in the pond, resulting pond will perform to its design efficiency which will improve the quality of the runoff released to the creeks. The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

The purpose of the permanent storage volume in a pond is to allow suspended solids (sediment) from the runoff to settle down in the pond bottom and release the treated water to the creek. Over the time, pond will accumulate sediment which will reduce the permanent storage, impacting the sediment removal efficiency of the pond drastically, resulting untreated water released to the Creek. properties.Name: Replacement of Single Train Membrane at Raymond A. Barker Water Treatment Plant located at 2 Raglan Street, Collingwood
properties.Description:
Project Description:This proposed upgrade will see the replacement of a single train of membranes at Raymond A. Barker Water Treatment Plant in order to increase treatment capacity and output supply of the Plant to meet the long-term water demands of Town of New Tecumseth (providing drinking water to a population of 24,800 for Alliston and Beeton). Drinking water is currently provided to Alliston and Beeton via a pipeline from Collingwood. The existing membranes have reached the end of their useful life and New Tecumseth is obligated to cost share in rehabilitation projects at the Raymond A. Barker Water Treatment Plant as outlined in the Primary Water Supply Agreement. The upgrades to the membranes will maintain treatment capacity levels and allow an increase in supply to the Town to meet the current water demands and long-term supply needs. Original timeframe for this upgrade was scheduled for 2018, and as a result of this funding the project can now be advanced, allowing for earlier implementation and ensuring the security of supply for the Town of New Tecumseth, including primary employers and essential health services such as Honda Manufacturing of Canada, Baxter Corporation, and Alliston Memorial Hospital.

properties.Name: Upgrade Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems for Cochenour Water Treatment Plant, Balmertown Reservoir Pumping Station and Madsen Water Treatment Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:***Modified project*** See notes for original project information The Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) enabled computers in these facilities date to the construction of the treatment facilities in 2005/06. 10-years has exceeded the service life of the computer hardware/software, and recently support for Windows XP has been discontinued. This would consist of upgrades of Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) hardware and programming. Existing PLCs are reaching capacity which will restrict future programming expansion. The OUTPUT to the community is the continued assurance of clean drinking water to the communities of Red Lake. Upgrades are as follows: Cochenour WTP;New SCADA Computer with SCADA software, PLC System. Cochenour WTP PLC, Balmertown Reservoir Pumping Station PLC and Low Lift Pump House PLC will be combined in to one PLC. Ethernet TCP-IP distributed I/O racks will be utilized. Low Lift Pump House will utilize existing fiber optic line from WTP to Low Lift Pump House. Installation and commissioning of new equipment. Programming of new system to function as per existing. Balmertown Reservoir Pumping Station:New SCADA Computer with SCADA software.New PLC System, Installation and commissioning, Programming to function as per existing. Madsen Water Treatment Plant: New SCADA Computer with SCADA software. New PLC System. Madsen Plant PLC, BCA PLC and Low Lift pumping Station PLC will be combined in to one PLC. Ethernet TCP-IP distributed I/O racks will be utilized. Low Lift Pumping Station will utilize existing fiber optic line from WTP to Low Lift Pumping Station. Installation and commissioning of new equipment. Programming of new system to function as per existing. The MECC requested the integration of flow monitors for chemical feed systems, complete with alarms and automatic shutdown. The Municipality responded that they will include the scope of work within the CWWF.

properties.Name: Detailed Water Treatment System Assessment and Infrastructure Planning
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will include the detailed water system assessment and infrastructure planning for the community, as needed to plan for the next 20 years. Our community is currently having extreme difficulty maintaining the required chlorine residual within our water system and adequate fire flows. We also struggle in providing our community with water supply security in the event of a watermain break due to numerous dead-ended watermains. The dead-ended watermains within out community do not promote "looping" or chlorine mixing for distributing required to maintain a satisfactory chlorine residual. It has therefore been difficult in many areas of our community to ensure safe drinking water in accordance with Ontario and Federal Regulations which results in a Health and Safety issue for our community members. Additionally, identifying the feasibility and costs of looping the water distribution system is essential in maintaining acceptable fire flows and to provide a more consistent pressure throughout the system. Maintaining an acceptable chlorine residual for safe potable drinking water is a critical health and safety requirement and it is also important for fire flow by looping the watermain. This is essential in providing our community with an effective disaster mitigation plan in the event of a fire emergency. Finally, identifying required upgrades to the watermain system is also important for the drinking water security of our community. In the current distribution system, if any watermain breaks occur in the community, dead ended areas in the community do not have access to safe drinking water. This assessment will help identify the next steps towards creating a safe drinking water system in accordance with Ontario and Federal Regulations which will eliminate the health and safety issue for the community members, reducing the potential for members to visit the provinces health care system.

Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Stormwater Collection Network Assessment and Study
properties.Description:
Project Description:"This project will identify, map, inspect, and complete a condition assessment of an estimated 56.5 kilometers of all natural and manmade storm water overland flow systems within the city limits. Overland water systems currently receive reactive maintenance only, and base level information regarding conditions is not known. The project data will capture critical information such as life cycle activities and asset life expectancy which are required for maintenance planning and execution. The project will provide base level (overland infrastructure) information that will form the foundation of an asset based GIS layer. This layer is intended to remain active, allowing for updates on inspections and condition assessments that will in turn guide future maintenance expenditures and provide system performance data. An updated life cycle investment profile will also be developed for the overland stormwater system based on the capital requirements for the renewal of the City's existing infrastructure. This project will consist primarily of experienced in-field inspectors identifying and assessing the condition of individual assets of the City's overland stormwater system via an asset record template. The inspectors will record the location (GPS) of each overland stormwater asset (linear or point feature) to create an updated GIS layer. Linear features will be divided by a determined length and managed as individual assets for efficient maintenance planning and expenditure. Asset valuation will also be recorded for different rehabilitation levels (if suitable for asset type), along with estimated replacement figures. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."

The scope of work is to engage a consulting engineer to complete the detailed design and associated tendering and construction administration tasks culminating in the selection of a contractor and the removal of the existing units , modification to existing electrical and installation of the replacement UV unit. During final design it was discovered that the concrete channel required improvements and adjustments to allow for more efficient operations of the new UV. In addition, an effluent level controller to minimize variations in flow to keep lamps at an ideal operating submersion and an operator SCADA interface was required at the UV panel. It was also identified that more programming was required for Module Communication Alarms. For health and safety reasons, a module lifting device was added which included a davit crane, base and lifting sling, hand winch including an adjustable boom and a swivel handle for rotation and positioning of the UV units. properties.Name: Stormwater Management Pond # PD03-02 Sediment Management
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will remove and dispose of 2,600 m3 of sediment from the pond. The project includes cleaning of outlets and restoration of the disturbed area. Majority of the Towns storm water ponds had been constructed with permanent storage volume (wet ponds). The purpose of the permanent storage volume in a pond is to allow suspended solids (sediment) from the runoff to settle down in the pond bottom and release the treated water to the creek. Over the time, pond will accumulate sediment which will reduce the permanent storage, impacting the sediment removal efficiency of the pond drastically, resulting untreated water released to the Creek. Realising a need for a pond clean out, Town of Whitby conducted a ponds need study in 2011 to evacuate the pond permanent storage capacity and learned majority of the ponds require cleanout as bathymetric survey revealed fair amount of sediment accumulated in the ponds. Under this project accumulated sediment in the pond will be removed allowing required permanent storage in the pond, resulting pond will perform to its design efficiency which will improve the quality of the runoff released to the creeks. The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2018-10-31

Upon reviewing the primary disinfection conditions, the MOECC requested a contact time study be conducted to confirm the primary disinfection capacity of the Cobalt (DWS). The new treatment facility will service the Municipality of Dysart et al, which has an estimated septage volume of 10,000 to 12,500 cubic meters per year. The Federal Wastewater Systems Effluents Regulations (2012) made under the Fisheries Act speaks directly to the issues that are relevant: http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2012-139/page-2.html#h-4.

properties.Name: Upgrading of water, wastewater and stormwater infrastructure on O'Meara Boulevard (Prospect Street to McCamus Avenue)
properties.Description:
Project Description:The proposed reconstruction project includes multiple components including storm sewer, watermain, and sanitary sewer construction. The project is within the Drainage area D10 includes O'meara blvd from intersection of Prospect Street to Mccamus Avenue within the Town of Kirkland Lake. The current public health and Safety problem impacting the residents within the area of reconstruction are related to all project components. 1. The Storm sewer is 81 years old. Storm sewer problems are quite visible each spring or with intense rainfalls causing flooding within the drainage area. The priority of these works considers firstly to prevent the health and safety concern of localized flooding. 2. The Sanitary system is 81 years old constructed with clay material which pass way beyond its life expectancy. Sanitary sewer breaks, blockages and sewer back ups into residential homes pose a significant Health and safety concern that must be avoided. Due to the age and material used to construct the system there is significant risk of failure. 3. The Water mains are also 86 years old and were constructed with Ductile Iron pipes. Watermain breaks occurs quite often in this section Despite an aggressive by-annual water main flushing program we continue to receive discolored water complains from residents within this area. Residents have been vocal in expressing their health concerns related to discolored water and the frequency which they encounter discolored water. Due to age and material of this section watermain there is a significant risk of contamination and health concern for local residents of this area. The Project would reduce the current public health and safety problems by way of the new infrastructure. New and properly sized storm system will reduce if not eliminate the localized flooding. New sanitary sewers will reduce the possibility of sewage backup into residents homes. New water-mains will reduce the instances of discolored water.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2018-07-06

properties.Name: Blower, rotating biological contactor Pump and Lift Station Pump installation
properties.Description:
Project Description:Purchase and installation of rotating biological contactor pump, blower rebuild and motor, and lift station 50 horsepower pump (new model with Nema B rated motor) are required as age of equipment could result in failure of wastewater system. Equipment within the system that is currently in use has proven to be of good quality and will be replaced "like for like". All are new models. The rotating biological contactor pump design is non-clog impeller and high efficiency with reduced energy costs of 25%. Technology has greatly improved over the years so not only are these pumps far more efficient but will also provide energy savings and reduce the risk of a catastrophic failure.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-01
Construction End Date:2018-06-01

properties.Name: The Morris Road Drain and Stormwater Management Facility
properties.Description:
Project Description:The Morris Road Drain and Stormwater Management (SWM) project will see the construction of a new stormwater facility which will reduce historical, local flooding issues and improve the water quality that is entering the Lake Simcoe basin as part of the uncontrolled stormwater coming from Bradford West Gwillimbury. 57% of Bradford West Gwillimbury is without stormwater control. The project captures an urban drainage area of 136 ha resulting in an increase in water quality controlled area from 33% to 41%. The work will include a new stormwater pond and the construction of approximately 750m of open channel in order to gain sufficient outlet. The Town's Morris Road Drain Report and the Comprehensive Stormwater Management Master Plan identify the opportunity for the new SWM to be constructed to address uncontrolled drainage and reduce impacts due to local flooding.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-10
Construction End Date:2018-01-31

properties.Name: Upgrading of perimeter Safety and Security Fencing to Wastewater Lagoon
properties.Description:
Project Description:The current regular farm fence around the lagoon was installed in 1994. Some posts are broken and it needs to be replaced. The lack of a security fence is making it easy for hunters and others to trespass on the property. Some kids have been seen playing in the area as well as wildlife. Foxes, skunks and the occasional bear have been seen on the perimeter. The open water at the lagoon is of great concern for public safety. The lagoon is located a short distance on the outskirts of town and it is not under supervision 24/7. We propose to install 990 meters of 8 feet high chain link fence complete with gates to secure the property.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-01
Construction End Date:2017-08-31

properties.Name: Purchase and installation of submersible mixer at Saugeen Composite Water tower
properties.Description:
Project Description:Project will supply and on-site install a GridBee GS-12-120v Submersible Mixer, including GS-Series Control Panel (with Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system capability) in the floor of the tank at the Saugeen composite tower, which is Saugeen's only water tower. This will eliminate ice damage, improve energy efficiency, reduce nitrification, as well as prevent stagnation, thermal stratification and short-circuiting. This initiative will immediately benefit the 2400 non-Native cottagers who lease land on Saugeen as well as Saugeen community members. The Nation will be able to provide certainty in water quality and delivery during high tourist season. This will improve service for over 800 Band members. This project will provide long term benefits for all members by continually assuring the safety and quality of our water tower and water system on a daily basis and moreover in emergency situations and continued assurance of reduced burden on the province's health care system.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-29
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Construction of a new Konkle Creek Stormwater Naturalization Corridor
properties.Description:
Project Description:Construction of a new 750m long naturalized creek corridor to improve both the management and treatment of stormwater as well as improving erosion and flooding conditions. The floodplain will increase the storm water capacity by 80% (approx. 57,000 cubic meters) in comparison to existing conditions. This new corridor will directly affect 40 adjacent properties (approx. 120 residents) and indirectly benefit 14 properties (42 residents). Konkle Creek is a major water course within the Town of Lincoln that flows down from the Niagara Escarpment through the Towns urban area to Lake Ontario. This water course experiences fast flowing stormwater conditions resulting in significant erosion and flooding damage to the creek channel as well as adjacent properties. General public safety is a concern as the current trail is closed and does not provide for safe public access. The proposed creek naturalization works will provide critical stormwater management needs for the Town and will also significantly improve the overall environmental health of the creek specifically, aquatic and terrestrial habitats. The new corridor will also improve public safety by restoring a public trail/walkway and by helping to reduce localized flooding an erosion to resident properties as well as public areas (the creek corridor and two neighbourhood parks). Additionally, the new corridor will reduce flooding and erosive flows downstream leaving the new creek corridor, reducing flooding pressures on public roadway culverts and bridges.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-18
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

The concrete storm sewers range in size from 300 mm to 600 mm in diameter. The rehabilitation will use industry approved trenchless technologies to repair noted areas of deterioration. properties.Name: Dufferin Street Sanitary Sewer - Replacement of vitrified clay pipe
properties.Description:
Project Description:OBJECTIVE: The Town is actively adopting wastewater infrastructure renewal projects that improve operation and maintenance requirements, reduce inflow and infiltration, provide enhancements to the natural environment and support long term sustainable infrastructure. SCOPE: The scope of this project includes the replacement of 352 metres of 300-375mm diameter vitrified clay sanitary sewers from Central Avenue to the Niagara Parkway that were constructed in 1925. The sanitary sewer is in a poor structural state and is beyond the end of its service life, as such, replacement of the sanitary sewer is the recommended rehabilitation alternative along with the replacement of maintenance holes and sanitary laterals. This is a priority project for the Town. Town Council has accelerated this project to design in 2016 and construction in 2017 through administrative report IS-22-2016. This project was originally forecast for design in 2018 with construction forecast for 2019. The design for this project is currently being completed by an engineering design firm with a planned 2017 construction start. OUTPUT: The estimated reduction in stormwater (inflow & infiltration) entering the wastewater distribution system is approximately 2,700 cubic meters per annum as a direct result of the replacement of the sanitary sewer, maintenance holes and service laterals. This project will directly contribute to reduce point source sanitary overflows to meet both regulatory requirements and objectives of the remedial action plan for the Niagara River.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-30
Construction End Date:2018-11-16

This would meet the funds goals of increasing the capacity or lifespan of the asset, enhancing service and improving environmental outcomes. Off reserve benefits: that extend beyond the on-reserve community by undertaking this project are that we will reduce our currently high phosphorous levels and relieve pressure from our current waste water treatment system which has been long operating at beyond design capacity as per a report published in 2006. The improvement of our Six Nations wastewater systems discharge into the McKenzie Creek and eventually into the Grand River will assist with water treatment for those municipalities who draw our effluent water downstream from the Grand River for potable water usage as well as help make rivers and lakes healthier, which would have a positive impact on municipal agricultural users and have an overall positive environmental impact on the Lake Erie Drainage Basin as well as help to achieve the phosphorous load reduction targets for Lake Erie as our wastewater effluent has been documented to have high phosphorous levels.

properties.Name: Hermitage Stormwater Management Pond Rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project includes the rehabilitation and repair of an online stormwater management facility. This involves the rechanneling of the main conveyance system and removal of existing trees that are adversely affecting the operation of the existing outlet structure. Constant blockages occur and are contributing to stagnant water conditions, which in turn has created an annual West Nile mosquito population, as documented by Durham Region Health. Minor or routine maintenance is garbage, debris and vegetation removal from a stormwater management facility. This project is a major repair and requires large excavation equipment which is not routine. This project will provide a significant improvement to a stormwater facility that is designed to store peak events and prevent basement, right of way and private properties to be flooded during storm events. As well as eliminating a public health risk to an abutting residential neighborhood.

properties.Name: Stamford Interceptor Renewal - Phase I (sewer lining & maintenance holds)- located in the City of Niagara Falls
properties.Description:
Project Description:** Modified project see notes for original information** "The scope change to the Stamford project involved the replacement of the first two maintenance holes and the section of sewer that joins them and the risks associated with doing so. The initial estimates did not include the open cut works. The project includes: (1) 2,200 meters of intercept sewer lining (ranges in size from 1050mm to 1200 mm; crosses under 3 roadways). (2) Replacement of 2 failed maintenance holes. (3) Rehabilitation of 26 maintenance holes. The project is incremental: even though a design was near completion, the project had been removed from our 2017 capital budget due to insufficient regional funding. The CWWF funding will allow us to proceed. The Stamford interceptor sewer is in service since 1964 and has extensive corrosion from hydrogen sulphide attack. Rehabilitation of the trunk sewer will provide a reliable and sustainable service to Niagara Falls residents, business and tourists. This project will be done by trenchless construction (insertion of a glass reinforced plastic pipe liner). This is typically cheaper and more resistant to corrosion. It will extend the life by over 50 years. In addition it has a smaller carbon foot print than traditional open-cut digging methods. Phase I consists of the rehabilitation of the trunk sewer from Dorchester Rd pump station to Portage Road. Currently the project is in preliminary design, the pipe condition is under review to determine if the pipe should be replaced or is eligible for trenchless technology lining. Construction from Dorchester Rd pump station to Drummond Rd pump station is scheduled to begin Fall 2016. The construction from Drummond Rd pump station to Portage Rd is scheduled to begin in 2017. The cost estimate is based on a recently completed project of similar nature and scope, and the constructability review estimate. Due to size and complexity of this project an extension beyond March 31, 2018 deadline is required
Construction Start Date:2018-05-15
Construction End Date:2019-01-30

A preliminary geomorphic study is required to assess the extent of the problem and develop concept design alternatives for sanitary protection works. This study will provide a better understanding of our local water resources and enable innovative designs to reduce sediment inputs into local waterways, improve habitat and provide infrastructure protection. This project is located between Highway 7 and Highway 407 ETR, south of Centre Street, in the City of Vaughan.
