properties.Name: Study update of storm sewer outfalls for Quality and Erosion Control Enhancement
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will complete a review of 44 storm sewer outfalls and 41 existing storm water ponds. Town of Whitby conducted a stormwater outfall study in 2001 to identify any locations where any additional quality and erosion control enhancement can be provided to improve the quality of the water released from the outfalls to the creek. Study revealed that majority of the outfalls constructed before the stormwater quality control concept, didnt have any quality control mechanism and recommended few locations for quality enhancement in the form of pond leaving many locations without any enhancement due to constructability or land issues including non availability of emerging technology at that time (ex; mechanical structures such as oil & grit separators and LID technology). Based on the original study six new stormwater facilities had been constructed under the pond program. Under this project, all the outfalls will be revisited and report will be updated and new prioritized locations will be identified for quality enhancement which will assist the Town to prepare a new pond retrofit program and implement under capital works or though any other funding opportunities. Due to weather-sensitive work that must be completed outside of winter months, we are requesting an extension beyond March 31, 2018, to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-12-01
Construction End Date:2018-09-30

properties.Name: Water Treatment Plant Improvement Project

properties.Name: Design and Installation of Inlet Control Devices in Bilberry/Chatelaine, Bridlewood North and Craig Henry (Storm water linear assets, appurtenances)
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project will mitigate the risk of basement flooding by retrofitting stormwater management devices. This is achieved by installing devices in catchbasins to control the stormwater capture rate to storm sewers design capacity at catchbasins to prevent sewer surcharge. We are installing devices that limit capture rate to between 6 Litres per second (L/s) and 15 L/s), 409 Inlet Control Devices (ICDs) Bilberry/Chatelaine; 409 ICDs Bridlewood North; 1362 ICDs Craig Henry. The nature and extent of the work are not feasibly achievable within a single construction season. We request an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline because the process to complete the design, procurement, and construction for this project requires additional time, and until federal funding is approved, the City cannot complete the procurement for construction.

Construction End Date:2019-10-12

The current corrugated metal pipe installed in the 1960's is showing signs of rust perforation. The pipe is located in the downtown core and crosses Main Street (Highway 17 Trans Canada Highway) which is the major arterial route through the City. A no dig technology is being recommended for this project in order to eliminate disruption to traffic and businesses based on the downtown core location of the works.

Construction End Date:2017-12-08

properties.Name: Storm Water Management Pond Cleaning by removal and disposal of sediment at 10 locations.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Removal and disposal of sediment in storm water ponds in order to operate properly, reduce risk of harm to fish habitat and in compliance with the Ministry of Environment conditions. Storm ponds are inspected regularly and are required to be cleaned in order to provide proper operating capacity and function. A Storm Water Management (SWM) pond is an engineered pond designed to control the quantity and quality of storm water prior to its discharge into the local water course to reduce the impacts of development on the watershed. The stormwater management pond controls the quantity of runoff water, prevents erosion and flood damage. The ponds are designed to collect water and allow sediment to settle to the bottom of the pond, instead of travelling downstream. As the pond collects the sediment over time the pond will then need to be cleaned out to allow more sediment to settle. A typical cleaning cycle is in the 5-10 year range. Location addresses are 1145 Thornton Road North; 1661 Harmony Road. North; 1072 Ridgemount Boulevard; 235 Howden Road East, 350 Woodmount Drive; 2120 Ritson Road North; 1035 Pondview Court; 1080 Townline Road South; 349 Britannia Avenue East; 1310 Beatrice Street East. The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-01
Construction End Date:2018-09-01

The scope of the project is to finalize the Environmental Assessment (EA) process to confirm the well location and construct the new production well and pumphouse in 2017. properties.Name: North St Boniface Water Main Upgrading
properties.Description:
Project Description:Water mains upsizing to provide adequate fire flow to support future multi-family development. The water mains proposed to be renewed in the North St Boniface area were installed in 1958 and are nearing the end of their service lives. The water mains to be renewed need to be upsized to provide the required level of service to accommodate the proposed growth, re-development and densification planned in the area. The primary goal of the project is to improve the available fire protection in the North St Boniface area in order to facilitate higher density redevelopment plans. There has been significant interest for multi-family development in this area but it has not been able to proceed due to available fire flows. Mains to be upsized are: Tache (La Verendrye to Messager), St. Joseph (La Verendrye to Messager), Messager (Tache to St Joseph), Hebert (Tache to St Joseph), Darveau (Tache to St Joseph), Grandin (Tache to St Joseph), Aubert (Tache to St Joseph), La Verendrye (Tache to Langevin), and Notre Dame (Tache to St Joseph). This project is being accelerated and is supporting the rehabilitation of water infrastructure as well as upgrading the existing water main system in the area to accommodate the needed level of service of near term future development in this area (which is a neighborhood renewal area).
Construction Start Date:2018-06-07
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Water treatment plant repairs - Inspect and repair or replace valves and piping in pump house due to leaks
properties.Description:

As well 2 American Water Works Association gate valves will be replaced with new Clow gate valves. There are leaks throughout piping which is covered with insulation. Line needs to be replaced as well as insulation. Service Watts pump control valves on well #1 and well #2 and replace copper tubing as required. There is another 6" valve located at the outlet of the pump house that needs to be replaced.

Please see notes for original project information*** "Twin the gravity sewer from Hope St. to the Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) to mitigate-by-pass during wet weather events. 660m of sanitary sewer twinning on Hope St. South/Lake Street from Shutter Street to east end of energy service company site (ESCO); 490m of sanitary sewer twinning on the easement through ESCO; 300m of sanitary sewer twinning north of Lake Street from Daylighting of Sewer to STP Headworks. The Sanitary Sewer Twinning project is located on Lake Street, commencing at Hope Street and extending to the Sewage Treatment Plant. The proposed alignment of the pipe and associated length of pipe has slightly changed from the original submission. The project now includes the installation of approximately 575m of 450mm diameter PVC sanitary sewer, 575m of 600mm diameter PVC sewer, concrete maintenance holes, connections to the existing system, by-pass sewer pumping, and approximately 330m of 600mm diameter above grade steel pipe construction including support piers and various other field connections. Due to delays in developing the agreement, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, resulting in an increase in Federal Funding of $55,144 to be reallocated from MPH002."

properties.Name: Upgrade Seasonal Water lines and Wastewater lines to heated lines for Year round accessibility throughout property
properties.Description:
Project Description:The upgrade to heated water lines and waste water lines will allow all year availability of water and wastewater. New water supply lines will give us the opportunity to isolate the direction of water flow, for flexibility, or isolating certain areas that is not needed. This will allow us to shut water off to areas in case of emergencies or repairs. Providing heat to our passive gray water system will ensure that the flow continues throughout the winter. The construction of a Well housing Facility will further protect the main well source by covering it from the elements and reducing major temperature fluctuations, which would otherwise affect the quality of the assets; rust, swelling, freezing. This housing will give full year round access to the main well fitting(s), no matter the environmental factors. The completion of this project will ensure that safe reliable water is available year round and reduce the impact on the province's health services. Off Reserve Band members will benefit from the project for when they return to the Missanabie First Nation to live or visit the water will be safe for consumption.

Since the closure of 'WELL 9' in 2013 due to high concentration of barium and sodium, "WELL 11" has been enduring an extreme amount of 'stress' as the main producing groundwater source well. As the system was designed based on '3' active WELLS, 'WELL 9" needs to be replaced. Replacing well #9 with another well will restore water capacity and water quality to the way the system was originally designed, so the off-reserve benefit is the community will not need to enter into a municipal type Agreement for supply.

Please see notes for original project information*** "The main process air blowers at the Greenway Wastewater Treatment Plant are 30-40 years old, are inefficient by current standards and have reached the end of their service life. Upgrading some of these blowers to more efficient Turbo blowers will save 3.38 million ekWh/year worth approximately $600,000. The electrical efficiency at the Pottersburg plant will also be improved with this new technology. A grant of $900k from the Independent Electricity System Operator is included as Other Contributions. Purchase of fourth blower for Greenway Section 3, as the existing blower failed to function properly in parallel with new blowers. Aeration field valve actuators have also been identified to be failing, without replacing these, the full energy efficiencies will not be realized. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, this will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $169,500.00 to be reallocated from LON-017 and LON-018."

properties.Name: River Road West Drainage Improvements & Urbanization
properties.Description:
Project Description:"River Road West Drainage Improvements & Urbanization (Brillinger Drive to Veterans Way) This project includes the installation of stormwater management facilities, including storm sewers and quality control structures. It will provide improved drainage facilities and stormwater quality control structures along the only Arterial Roadway in Wasaga Beach prior to its discharge into the Nottawasaga River. The Nottawasaga River ultimately discharges to the Nottawasaga Bay, adjacent to the Towns Main Beach Area and Ontario Parks Environmental lands. The storm sewer installation will require the installation of curb & gutters and sidewalks as part of the urbanization of River Road West, providing greater transportation safety for motorists, pedestrians and cyclists and addressing uncontrolled stormwater runoff along this principle transportation corridor. This project aligns well with the funding program in addressing improved access, increased mobility and extension of the life of the existing asset as well as collection, conveyance and treatment of surface water runoff before entering the Nottawasaga River. This project is also the highest priority road and drainage project in the Towns Capital Works Plan. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."

The scope of this project is to: pump down the holding tank, replace aging, corroded piping, guide rails, refurbish the pumps, inspect and repair any cement cracks or deterioration. The expected outcome is to extend the useful life of the Wastewater Pump Station to ensure it can reliably convey wastewater through to the Treatment Plant.

properties.Name: Rehabilitation design and construction of Drinkwater Stormwater Pond failed outfall and study of rehabilitation options to add water quality and erosion control functions (up to 30 outfalls and ponds)
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Revised project *** See Keynotes for previous information The project will address a current safety hazard due to the deteriorating outfall at Drinkwater pond and examine options for improving the function of the pond. The work will include the design, contract administration and construction of a new pond outfall structure and outlet channel. Stormwater management facilities that were identified in the City's Stormwater Management Pond Retrofit Study will have designs prepared to improve the functions of the ponds with respect to water quality and erosion control. The outcome of the project will be the elimination of an existing hazard and the creation of up to 30 shovel ready projects to improve stormwater management. The $900,000 decrease in total project costs (i.e. $450,000 in federal CWWF funding) is due to a reduced scope of work. The project will no longer undertake the construction of the retrofit to the forebay and main cell of the Drinkwater Pond and the construction component of the project will focus on the rehabilitated outfall only. The "study" component of the project, that will examine retrofit opportunities for 30 additional ponds and prepare design drawings, will remain within the scope of work. Due to delays in the development of the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delay in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline.

Construction End Date:2018-03-31

The new water standpipe will: increase the capacity of water supply and storage, increase water pressure to ensure adequate pressure is provided throughout the water distribution system, meet emergency fire protection and fire storage demands, improve energy efficiency, extend the water systems useful life, and decrease operation and maintenance costs. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.

properties.Name: Water Treatment Plant Chlorination Analysis Improvements
properties.Description:
Project Description:**Modified project** See notes(original) This project will install a new sample line for chlorine outside the building on the header pipe and a new chlorine analyzer on the nearest wall to reduce the delay in obtaining readings of the chlorine concentration. Also, this project will allow the purchase and the installation of a new groundwater pump to replace an existing old pump (Pump #2). Our water plant (WT) pumps water to the distribution and the reservoir in a fill and drain cycle, allowing the water pumps to rest in between cycles. While the reservoir is off-line and isolated for repairs the water supply water will come from the WP pumps, running continuously. Should a pump shut down, the plant would switch to the second pump. During this period the Town would be relying on 2 groundwater supply wells at the WTP. Pump #1 is new (2011); Pump #2 was installed in 1949. The most recent inspection said it is beyond repair. A quote to replace Pump #2 and air scour Well #2 has been provided ($48,104.00) by International Well Supply (IWS). IWS was the original well driller/pump installer when our wells were installed 65 years ago. IWS employs a crew of licenced well drillers and engineers that have the expertise to source replacements and conduct installations. Both our wells are approx. 10-15 feet apart; they are hydraulically connected, and service on one well/pump affects the other. It iscritical that anyone performing maintenance activities on either well have the knowledge and experience to ensure the continued supply of drinking water throughout the procedure. We haveworked closely with the Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change and IWS to accomplish this safely, using protocols that will only apply to Mattawa and IWS. Should the Project Scope Change be successful, our intention is to sole source the replacement pump and maintenance to IWS. Pending approval. Once approved, delivery is 6-8 weeks. Flushing water after installation requires a spring install.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-05
Construction End Date:2018-05-31

properties.Name: Rehabilitation of the Stormwater Pond at Mayfield Road and Heart Lake Road
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** modified projects *** See in notes for original information "The purpose of this project is to restore the original facility functions to protect the environment, enhance the ability of the region through improved technology to operate and maintain the infrastructure, improve the infrastructure efficiency and reduce long term maintenance costs. Rehabilitation and retrofitting of the storm water pond at Mayfield Road and Heart Lake Road to restore the original operational design parameters and to meet the current standards for providing flood control and an ""enhanced level of protection"". The facility was constructed to service a tributary area of 22.3 ha, being comprised of 8.7 ha of arterial road drainage and 13.6 ha lands additional area which drains to the arterial road right of way. This facility provides storm water Quality Control (Enhanced Level i.e. 80% Total Suspended Solids removal) and Erosion Control and maintain Water Quantity flows below existing flow rates up to an including the Regional Storm. On June 6, 2008 the Ministry of Environment authorized the Region to construct, operate and maintain the prescribed infrastructure, provided that it properly operate and maintain the infrastructure to protect the environment. To demonstrate compliance with the MOE authorization the Region of Peel operates a monitoring program. This program has illustrated that the original design performance characteristics have deteriorated and that without rehabilitation, the facility will not provide the function as per its original design. Due to delays in developing the agreement and consequent local priority changes, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. Unique solutions/new technology - (SWMshield) was implemented in the design process which substantially reduced cost. In addition, economies of scale (by tendering 3 storm water ponds - PEEL-01, PEEL-02 & PEEL-31) resulted in lower tender price.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-01
Construction End Date:2017-12-31

properties.Name: Moore Crescent Sewage Pumping Station Renovations
properties.Description:
Project Description:The objective of this project is primarily to complete upgrades at the Moore Crescent Sewage Pumping Station. This is to include upgrades to the existing incoming master control center (MCC) panels as well as replacement of the existing 20kW diesel generator and electric heater that have reached the end of their useful lives. The scope of work is to engage a consulting engineer to complete the detailed design and associated tendering and construction administration tasks culminating in the selection of a contractor and the replacement of the existing MCC panels with Variable Frequency Drives and associated controls. The MCC is to include Programmable Logic Controller and Ethernet connections and be connected to the Towns existing SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) system through an antenna or cell phone connection as appropriate. The work is also to include the replacement of the Miltronics level control unit and the addition of an electromagnetic flow meter in both pumping stations. The existing electric heating is to be replaced with a new system such as natural gas. The existing transfer switches are expected to be reused along with the existing dialers however a condition evaluation is to be completed.

The new sanitary sewer main will consist of 1210m of new 8 main, and 16 new 1050mm manholes, with all new services into the property line of the houses. This section of the project is part of the original structure built in the 1960s, and the community has been experiencing flow issues and blockages. The project will also provide a much needed upgrade to our storm water system that has been causing serious ice issues, as well shoulder wash outs for many years. This upgrade to our system will consist of 650m of new 750mm storm main and 50m of 600mm storm main, with eight new 1500mm catch base and numerous sluice boxes to pick up low areas on the properties.

Construction End Date:2018-04-16

properties.Name: Water treatment plant upgrade - Perform engineering study to design and install a contact time return line from contact chamber to analyzer.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Perform engineering study to design and install a contact time (CT) return line from contact chamber to the analyzer. The study is needed so that changes can be made to the process configuration so that there is a quicker water quality reading to the analyzer. This will enable the process to react more quickly. The quicker reaction will prevent boil water advisories and ensure a more stable water quality. At this time it is unknown if the water quality information is getting to the controller fast enough.
Construction Start Date:2017-01-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Mornington Area Storm Drainage Servicing - Environmental Assessment
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Identifying an outlet and strategy for storm drainage for this area of the City will allow the separation of existing combined sewers. It will also help allow an existing storm/relief sewer which currently conveys some of these storm flows to be rededicated as a sanitary relief sewer. Future projects will be identified. Scope of work for the successful consultant was reduced due to knowledge gained during previous work done by the same company. IO NOTE: There is a decrease in scope. This will result in a decrease in Federal Funding of $159,200.00 to be reallocated to LON-003 and LON-013."
Construction Start Date:2017-10-30
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Extension of water and sanitary services to the Cedar Heights area.
properties.Description:
Project Description:The proposed project would involve the installation of water services (including transmission and distribution water mains, a standpipe and a pumping station) and sanitary services along a 1.5km stretch of Larocque Road. The infrastructure would service 12 dwellings on Larocque Road currently on private services and would facilitate additional future residential development in the area. In particular, an application for a 72 lot subdivision was received for a property on Larocque Road in 2011 that requires access to the proposed services in order to move forward. A number of large vacant properties are also available in the area for similar development proposals. In addition, the proposed water services would provide more secure fire flow for the Nipissing University and Canadore College campus located to the South. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-01
Construction End Date:2019-06-30

properties.Name: Hamilton Street Sewer Separation - Removal/disposal of existing sanitary sewers and replacement with a new storm sewer.  Removal/disposal of existing watermain and replacement with a new watermain.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Includes capital construction on 3 streets; Hamilton, Homewood and Menzie Street Project is needed for sewer separation; reduce basement flooding potential downstream and combined sewer overflow events. Watermain and roads are in poor condition. Hamilton: Limits extend from Sixth Avenue to Stanley Avenue. Replace combined Sewer with 390 meter of new Sanitary sewer ranging in diameter from 200mm to 375mm and 385 meter of new Storm Sewer ranging in diameter from 375mm to 900 mm. 380 meter of new 150mm diameter Watermain and Road Reconstruction ( including new sidewalks, curb and gutter). Project includes new sanitary laterals with cleanouts at the property line and new water services with curb stops at the property line for 32 lots. Homewood : Limits extend from Bridge St. to North limit. Replace Combined Sewer with 190 meter of new Sanitary Sewer ranging in diameter from 200 mm to 375mm and 130 meter of new Storm Sewer ranging in diameter from 375mm to 900 mm. 200 meter of new 150mm diameter Watermain and Road Reconstruction including new sidewalks, curb and gutter. Project includes new sanitary laterals with cleanouts at the property line and new water services with curb stops at the property line for 23 lots. Menzie St: Limits extend from Homewood Ave. to Stanley Ave. Replace Combined Sewer with 210 meter of new Sanitary Sewer ranging in diameter from 200 mm to 375mm and 200 meter of new Storm Sewer ranging in diameter from 375mm to 900mm. 200 meter of new 150mm diameter Watermain and Road Reconstruction including new sidewalks, curb and gutter. Project includes new sanitary laterals with cleanouts at the property line and new water services with curb stops at the property line for 26 lots. Hydrants will be replaced for each as well.
Construction Start Date:2017-11-02
Construction End Date:2018-07-01

properties.Name: Lift Station SCADA
properties.Description:
Project Description:This supervisory control and data acquisition project will enable the city to get real time information on our 12 sewage lift stations (throughout the city) and our one lagoon. The ability to see the operations of our system twenty four hours a day 365 days a year enables our staff to detect problems as they occur and rectify them remotely before they become a threat to the environment or our residents' property. The project would involve the installation of hardware and fiber at all of our stations to communicate to the central computer system at our operations facility.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Water Reservoir Dechlorinator.  Purchase and installation of new equipment (Michipicoten River Village)
properties.Description:
Project Description:***Modified project*** See notes for original project information. "We will purchase and install a dechlorinator. Trihalomethanes have been discovered in the drinking water in Wawa. While the Municipality continues to work on a solution to this problem, it is requried to ""spill"" signifcant amounts of water from its reservoir at this lcoation in order to reduce the level of Trihalomethanes. The Ministry of the Enviroment requries that this water is free of chlorine. While the existecne of the Trihalomethanes is exepcetd to be alleviated it is very possible that they may re-occur agian requiring the spilling of drinking water. The dechlorinator will greatly assist in ensuring action can be taken promptly to alleviate all concerns. Addition of a chlorine analyser and pump to be installed at the water tower to allow for more efficient monitoring of chlorine residual and scrubbing of the water main after the project is complete. Project is complete and there has been a decrease in the cost associated to this project due to the bidder awarded being local and no additional fee for mob/demob and accomodations for meals/room & board allowed for a savings in cost on this project. IO NOTE: There is no decrease in scope, only a decrease in tender. This will result in a decrease in Federal Funding of $37,500 to be reallocated to WAW-001."
Construction Start Date:2017-03-15
Construction End Date:2018-02-01

properties.Name: Green Acres Sanitary Pumping Station in Grand Bend - Life Safety and Electrical upgrades and Installation of New  Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA)
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "The Green Acres pumping station upgrade will involve the replacement of life safety equipment in the form of ladders and walkways as well as electrical and pump upgrades. A new Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system will be installed as well. The additional electrical work was found during detail design of the project and is required to be able to undertake the current scope. Extension rationale: The Municipality was delayed on these projects due to the late commitment of funding. The delayed funding made it difficult to complete design, competitively source contractors and complete construction within the originally given date. This was compounded by the seasonality of the projects which cannot be completed during the winters months. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, resulting in an increase in Federal Funding of $5,445 to be reallocated from LAM-005."
Construction Start Date:2017-07-02
Construction End Date:2018-11-15

properties.Name: Preliminary Design of the Vanier Parkway Storm Sewer Renewal
properties.Description:
Project Description:This design only project will complete the design for future replacement 850m of the existing Corrugated steel pipe or Concrete storm sewer (1500mm/1800mm). The sewer is located in the Vanier Parkway from Glynn Avenue to Presland Road Presland road from the Vanier Parkway to Renouf Avenue as well as 240m of sewer located behind homes upstream of Presland Road. The sewer is shallow and oversized and therefore preliminary investigation suggests open-cut rehabilitation for this sewer. The existing storm sewer in the Vanier Parkway is located off the road within the treed boulevard. The design assignment will include relocating the storm sewer within the road corridor. The design will determine the exact requirements.
Construction Start Date:2017-03-17
Construction End Date:2019-01-01

properties.Name: Watermain Looping Completion for Village of Clarence-Creek
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Drinking Water Distribution for expansion to accommodate existing infrastructure pressures. Under the Infrastructure Stimulus Funding program, the City of Clarence-Rockland was able in 2010-11 to extend watermain infrastructure into two main rural villages and distribute to most residents within villages, however provisions for watermain looping were deemed unaffordable at the time. This project will complete a watermain looping for the village of Clarence Creek, (preference to complete both villages). A new section of 300mm watermain of 1.70 km in length on Landry Road between Henri Rd. and Du Golf Rd. will loop that village's drinking water network. About 50 additional residences will enjoy access to drinking water. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."
Construction Start Date:2017-12-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Water Supply Well No. 3 and Water Supply Main
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project work will include: - New well; - Water treatment and pump building; - Back up generator; and, - Water supply main.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-12
Construction End Date:2018-10-19

properties.Name: Water Main Rehabilitation 2019 - Upgrading of Cast Iron Water to PVC including Isolation Valves, Hydrants, and Service Connections
properties.Description:
Project Description:"The scope of the project includes: Replacement of 2155m of cast iron water (150mm and 200mm diameter) main using an open cut method with new Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) water main. Replacement of all connected water main appurtenances (includes fire hydrants, isolation valves, and water services from the water main to the property line). Approximately 430 residents will be directly impacted and 860 residents will be indirectly impacted. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."
Construction Start Date:2017-10-10
Construction End Date:2018-09-01

properties.Name: Install a backup generator for the water treatment facility
properties.Description:
Project Description:The backup generator will be installed at our water treatment facility. This 22kw propane generator will provide power to our facility in the event of a power outage or during a schedule power outage. The water treatment facility services 68 households and 5 community owned buildings. The quote for the water pump and installation is attached. Successful completion of this project will ensure that untreated wastewater does not enter the environment and negatively impact surrounding communities.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-03
Construction End Date:2018-03-30

properties.Name: Purchase new well level probe for main well for the township which serves 440 residents and 160 service connections. Located at the Elk Lake Water Treatment plant, 4 First Street.
properties.Description:
Project Description:To remove the defective well probe and replace with a new working probe to enable the well level to be monitored as a means of protecting the well pump and monitoring the performance of the aquifer as there is presently only one well. Scope: Remove old well probe, purchase, install and test the new well probe. Output: Fully functional well probe.
Construction Start Date:2017-01-05
Construction End Date:2017-01-09

properties.Name: Sludge Thickening Planning Project
properties.Description:
Project Description:The District of Taylor (District) is seeking funding to complete a sludge thickening planning project. The wastewater treatment plant assessment will identify any components of the District's existing plant that are not consistent with the municipal wastewater regulation (MWR) and provide upgrade options. This project will provide a list of necessary physical and operational upgrades required to bring the existing treatment process and plant into conformance with the MWR. The assessment will result in recommendations to improve monitoring and for process changes.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-10
Construction End Date:2018-02-28

properties.Name: Upgrade to Radio Communications for Water and Sewage Facilities
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will enable water and sewage infrastructure to communicate via radio waves for monitoring and alarming. This project ties together one wastewater plant, two water booster stations, and two key sewage pumping stations all located in the Villages of L'Orignal and Vankleek Hill. The project will eliminate the use of antiquated relay based communication boards which are no longer the industry standard.
Construction Start Date:2017-01-02
Construction End Date:2017-12-20

properties.Name: Conduct a Study and Videography (camera) of the Town's Wastewater Collection System
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Study and videography to assess the condition of the sewer system and identify any infiltration or other issues so corrective actions can be done or budgeted for as grants become available as well as be used to update our asset management plan - the system was built in 1976 In addition to the collection system pipes needing the camera inspection done, the project requires that the 103 manholes also be video graphed to determine the integrity of the system and any infiltration issues. The addition of the man hole camera work is an increase in scope of the project and therefore we are requesting the additional funding from the balance of the aeration system be moved to this project. Rationale for extension: The Study and Videography was delayed last fall due to the weather as there were concerns that as the cold weather approached, the camera would fog up and we wouldn't have a true, clear video of our system. Also, the availability of contractors that do this type of work was limited. Since OCWA is assisting us in overseeing this project, the sewer levels are higher in the spring. Due to delays in developing the agreement, an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline is required. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope that will result in an increase in Federal Funding of $7,500.00 reallocated from BMIN-002."
Construction Start Date:2017-04-01
Construction End Date:2018-09-30

properties.Name: Chipman Hill - Sewer Separation, Watermain, and Sanitary Sewer Renewals
properties.Description:
Project Description:Separation of combined sanitary/storm sewer and renewal of watermain and sanitary sewer along Chipman Hill from Union Street to King Street. This project includes related road work necessary to complete the project.
Construction Start Date:2019-07-01
Construction End Date:2019-10-31

properties.Name: Sewage Lift Station - Safety Landing Rehabilitation
properties.Description:
Project Description:Rehabilitation of concrete structure and safety landing of Sewage Lift Station as it is a safety risk due to corrosion (Asset#400400-01 CC#B2 2.9). Located at Middlemiss Drive and Chippewa Road. The efficient and safe operation of the station will ensure that no additional burden is placed on the Provincial health system, due to accidents, surrounding communities due to station issues.
Construction Start Date:2017-01-03
Construction End Date:2017-04-30

properties.Name: Repairs and upgrades to culverts on Takwata Drive.
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replace culvert at Marina Road. Reset culvert at Band Office entrance. Patch manholes. The manholes are a small but a vital component of the overall system. They are used to carry out inspections, cleaning and removing obstruction in the lines. Off-reserve benefits are protection to receiving environment.
Construction Start Date:2017-02-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-01

properties.Name: South Park, Strachan, and Harvey Street Sewer Separation and Water main upgrade
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "The Sanitary and Storm Sewer Separation Project will see the installation of new sanitary sewers and storm sewers. The storm and sanitary sewer work will eliminate any catch basins, cross connections and drainage issues which allow storm water runoff to directly enter the sanitary sewer system on the subject streets. When completed, this measure will collectively reduce extraneous flow in the sanitary sewer system and at the water pollution control plant. This will also result in a reduction in deteriorated treatment plant effluent released in to the environment and an improvement to the water quality of the receiving water body; the Bay of Quinte, which is the community's drinking water source. The old 1920's water main on South Park and Harvey Street will also be upgraded and replaced as part of this project. This is expected to increase fire flows in the area. Strachan St; From: North Front St, to: St Charles St (approx. 320), South Park St; All (approx. 100m), Harvey St; All (approx. 100 m) Extension Rationale: The recent extension request to December 31, 2019 is necessary to ensure there is sufficient time available to complete the construction work related to this latest scope change request January 1, 2018, consisting of the additions of Harvey St and remainder of Strachan). IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, resulting in an increase in Federal Funding of $518,917.00 reallocated from BEL-002."
Construction Start Date:2017-10-23
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Grand Allée Naturalized Wet Pond
properties.Description:
Project Description:Construction of a stormwater detention basin to temporarily store stormwater runoff from the Shediac Road and release it at a controlled rate to the existing piped stormsewer system.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-05
Construction End Date:2019-06-30

properties.Name: Pincher Creek - Beaver Mines Regional Water Supply
properties.Description:
Project Description:Construction of approximately 14.7 km of 150mm water transmission pipeline from the Cowley/Lundbreck Regional Water Treatment Plant to the Hamlet of Beaver Mines. The project will also include minor improvements to the water treatment plant.
Construction Start Date:2016-07-31
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Rural Waterline Expansion
properties.Description:
Project Description:Extend existing pipeline system by 55 kms to service 50 residences and a Hutterite Colony. Water supplies in the RM are not fit for human consumption.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-05
Construction End Date:2017-09-20

properties.Name: Rural Waterline Expansion
properties.Description:
Project Description:Purchase treated water from the Town of Neepawa and construct 25 kms of rural pipelines to service 25 rural properties, Hutterite Colony and Community of Eden. Water supplies in the area are extremely limited and of poor quality not fit for human consumption.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-14
Construction End Date:2018-01-29

properties.Name: Modernization of former CFB Chatham Water Distribution System
properties.Description:
Project Description:Improve water quality and pressure in the CFB Chatham Area by creating two water pressure zones. Includes: new booster station, additional SCADA elements, retrofit to well houses for pressure reducing valves and to a booster station, and decommissioning two concrete storage tanks and a booster station.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-17
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Faro pumphouses rehabilitation and reservoir upgrades
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replacement of four water pumphouses, replacement water reservoir with increased capacity, upgrade of monitoring stations, change chlorine injection and installation of controls (SCADA). Inclusion of decommissioning reservoir tanks.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-11
Construction End Date:2018-10-31

properties.Name: Water Supply Improvements
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project entails the complete reconstruction of the wooden portion of the dam, right down to the concrete base. As well, the pipe leading from the water supply to neighbouring Young's Pond will be extended, thus placing it in deeper water ensuring adequate flow all year long.
Construction Start Date:2018-06-01
Construction End Date:2018-12-30

properties.Name: Rehabilitation of Water System - Reservoir and Pumphouse
properties.Description:
Project Description:Rehabilitation of the Riverside Street Pumping Station. Includes building, equipment, and safety upgrades. Repair internal and external coating on the Village's water reservoir.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-26
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Pipe coating, separation and loopback
properties.Description:
Project Description:Principale Street and Martin Road sewer pipe coating, St-Joseph Street, as well as other streets in the community, combined sewer separation, O'Neill and St-Joseph Street loopback. This project includes the associated road work necessary to complete the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-30
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: Rural Waterline Expansion
properties.Description:
Project Description:Extend existing pipeline system by 55 kms to service 50 residences and a Hutterite Colony. Water supplies in the RM are not fit for human consumption.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-05
Construction End Date:2017-09-20

properties.Name: Rural Waterline Expansion
properties.Description:
Project Description:Purchase treated water from the Town of Neepawa and construct 25 kms of rural pipelines to service 25 rural properties, Hutterite Colony and Community of Eden. Water supplies in the area are extremely limited and of poor quality not fit for human consumption.
Construction Start Date:2017-08-14
Construction End Date:2018-01-29

properties.Name: Assessment and cleaning Oversized Storm Pipes Throughout Aurora
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will inspect and clean (as necessary) 20 storm 'superpipes' (storm equalization tanks). These storm tanks vary in both width (diameter) from 1m to 4m (975mm to 4.27mm) and in length from 14m to 102m. The tanks require inspection, assessment and cleaning so that grit and debris do not collect within the tank and at the restrictors, causing any form of buildup or overflow beyond their design storage capacity. The scope and cost estimate for the project does include cleaning of the tank.
Construction Start Date:2017-04-15
Construction End Date:2017-12-31

properties.Name: Bayfield Wastewater System Inflow and Infilitration Study
properties.Description:
Project Description:In two of the last three years, wastewater flows to the Bayfield Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) have exceeded the ECA rated capacity. To reduce flows to the WWTP, the Municipality is proposing an investigation into infiltration and inflow into the system. To date, 10% of the sewer system has been investigated, with the preliminary findings establishing that approximately 59% of existing flow is groundwater infiltration and inflow. The proposed study will examine the remaining 90% of the sewer system.
Construction Start Date:2016-06-01
Construction End Date:2018-09-30

properties.Name: Construction of Low Impact Development Stormwater Management Facilities in the McVicar Creek Basin
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project includes the construction of five (5) Low Impact Development (LID) stormwater management facilities within the McVicar Creek watershed. Funding includes $12,000 from Environment Canada (Great Lakes Sustainability Fund). The project sites are to be located on: - Bruce Street & Theresa Street (#1) - Biofiltration facility to treat 52 cubic meters of runoff from approximately 0.8 hectares of drainage area, footprint 115 sq.-m; - Bruce Street & Theresa Street (#2) - Biofiltration facility to treat 28 cubic meters of runoff from approximately 0.4 hectares of drainage area, footprint 62 sq.-m; - Olympia Place - Biofiltration facility to treat 99 cubic meters of runoff from approximately 1.4 hectares of drainage area, footprint 218 sq.-m; - Hinton Avenue - Biofiltration facility to treat 572 cubic meters of runoff from approximately 8.3 hectares of drainage area, footprint 625 sq.-m; - Hartviksen Street - Biofiltration facility to treat 37 cubic meters of runoff from approximately 0.5 hectares of drainage area, footprint 81 sq.-m;
Construction Start Date:2018-06-01
Construction End Date:2019-10-01

properties.Name: Highgate Road Drainage Improvements including Design and Construction
properties.Description:
Project Description:Allowance for design, construction and contract administration associated with the drainage improvements on Highgate Road. Directly improves drainage to 12 households with a total ditch length of approximately 630 metres.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-01
Construction End Date:2020-03-31

properties.Name: Treatment plant (in the Mares Noires western sector)
properties.Description:
Project Description:The work consists in making changes to the wasterwater treatment system, adding control instruments and making changes to the building. The addition of three lift stations and changes to the transfer room are also proposed.
Construction Start Date:2017-10-10
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Rehabilitate Septic System at 163 Main Street Location
properties.Description:
Project Description:Replacement and upgrade of Lions Park septic system to ensure ecological viability and safety of nearby lake water and ensure the correct capacity requirements of the septic system are met as both visitor numbers and local population figures grow. The "outhouse" facilities will be replaced with actual washrooms, ensuring health and safety of all users, as well as enabling year-round use.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-01
Construction End Date:2020-03-31

properties.Name: Development and Implementation of a GIS Strategy for Water and Wastewater Linear Assets
properties.Description:
Project Description:Develop and implement GIS strategy for water and wastewater linear systems using recognized water / wastewater industry GIS software such as ArcGIS and Esri. Data to be collected will include asset location, asset number, maintenance activities against asset and asset condition for water and wastewater assets including valves, chambers, fire hydrants and residential water meters. Develop tools for data collection and analytics for operational evidence-based decision making and long term asset management strategies. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-19
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Study and mitigation of the thermal effects of stormwater by investigating methods to reduce stormwater discharge temperatures through pilot projects (construction).
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Revised project *** See Keynotes for previous information Innovative technologies and inlet designs are available for use in stormwater ponds and this project will pilot several technologies in order to determine if the effects on discharge temperature can be reduced. Successful projects will improve aquatic habitats in receiving rivers. Baseline data will be established to assist with endangered species protection and to analyze performance of stormwater improvement measures including stormwater ponds and low impact development techniques. The $157,616 increase in total project costs (i.e. $78,808 in federal CWWF funding) is due to an increase in the amount of pilot projects from 2 projects to 4 projects. Due to delays in the development of the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delay in procurement, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline.
Construction Start Date:2017-07-02
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: CCTV of Lakeside Neighbourhood Sanitary Sewers
properties.Description:
Project Description:The neighbourhood of Lakeside is one of the oldest sections of Kenora and as such has most of its sanitary sewers approaching 100 years of age. The last major CCTV program conducted in Kenora was in the 1980's. The CCTV study will assist in asset management planning by way of collecting more current information on the condition of the approximately 12 km of sanitary mains.
Construction Start Date:2018-02-26
Construction End Date:2018-07-14

properties.Name: Preliminary Design for the Convent Glen North Storm Sewer
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** "Works were successfully completed under budget and expanded scope (detailed design as well). Seeking ability to move the excess funds to another approved project with an increased scope of delivery. Original project budget was based on high-level (conceptual) estimates. The estimates were refined through the preliminary design process identified the opportunity to also undertake the work necessary to reach construction-ready (tender) status. The Convent Glen Storm Trunk identified for rehabilitation work extends from the north side of RR174 in the Orleans N-W neighborhood discharging into the Ottawa River. The original pipes were 3000 mm - 4500 mm in diameter, made of Structural Plate Corrugated Steel (SPCSP) vertical ellipse shape (VE) and extend for approximately 1.44km Through detailed investigation revealed several locations with severe corrosion as well as associated appurtenances in poor shape unsafe to use (i.e. maintenance holes unsafe for access), thus the sewer is recommended for rehabilitation. The 3000/4500mm CSP sewer is located west of Jeanne D'Arc Blvd and runs behind homes and under pathways within City owned parcels. This project will provide for the design of the trunk sewer using trenchless methods of rehabilitation. This is recommended for this deep sewer. This project is to complete the preliminary design to rehabilitate 1430m of the trunk storm sewer from the north side of RR174 to the outlet at the Ottawa River. The 3000/4500mm Corrugated Steel Pipe (CSP) sewer is located west of Jeanne D'Arc Blvd and runs behind homes and under pathways within City owned parcels. We request an extension to the March 31, 2018 deadline because the nature and magnitude of the design work requires more time. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, accompanied by a decrease in tender. This will result in a decrease in Federal Funding of $287,500 to be reallocated to OTT-005."
Construction Start Date:2017-07-17
Construction End Date:2018-12-31

properties.Name: Lagoon Upgrade
properties.Description:
Project Description:Expansion of lagoon required to meet population growth as well as upgrade to phosphorus removal required to meet Water Quality Standards, Objectives and Guidelines Regulation under The Water Protection Act effluent quality standards.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-12
Construction End Date:2018-10-31

properties.Name: Equipment Replacement at the G.E. Booth Water Pollution Control Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** modified project *** see notes for original information "Equipment replacement at the G.E Booth Water Pollution Control Plant not covered under the OCWA operating contract. Recent condition assessments have indicated a list of various pieces of equipment are rapidly reaching the end of their useful life. Equipment to be replaced or refurbished include the following: thermal oxidation units, ash pumps, chemical tanks, grinders, compressors, blowers, screens, boilers, centrifuges, pumps, mixers and upgrades to plant lighting. The G.E Booth facility has additional pieces of equipment and structures that are at end of useful life and will be rehabilitated or replaced. The additional project includes site works, concrete, masonry and general requirements for the purpose of plant inlet sewer upgrades. IO NOTE: There is an increase in scope, resulting in an increase in Federal Funding of $3,150,000 to be reallocated."
Construction Start Date:2017-05-01
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Brighton Street sanitary sewer replacement from Garnet Street to Facer Street
properties.Description:
Project Description:260m replacement of 375mm diameter existing sanitary (combined) sewer. Project directly impacts 38 properties. Project in conjunction with storm sewer installation and watermain replacement
Construction Start Date:2017-10-23
Construction End Date:2018-03-31

properties.Name: Capital Improvements to the Pumping Station at the Lorne Park Water Treatment Plant
properties.Description:
Project Description:"Replacement of discharge valves and motor starters for seven high lift pumps and six low lift pumps in the pumping station at the Lorne Park Water Treatment Plant. Most of the equipment in the Lorne Park pumping station is original from 1975 and is approaching the end of its useful life. The Lorne Park facility is relied upon by approximately 500,000 residents in the western portion of Peel Region. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project."
Construction Start Date:2017-07-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Vermilion Bay Water Treatment Plant, 8 Bay Street, Vermilion Bay Ontario. System control and Data acquisition upgrading serving 218 services or approximately 550 people.
properties.Description:
Project Description:The existing System Control and Data Acquisition system (SCADA) is now 11 years old and has been recently showing signs of failure requiring the replacement of some equipment consideration for updating the Programmable Logic Controllers, either net switches, printer equipment and System Control and Data Acquisition system (SCADA) Computers will be required within the next 5 years. This would be considered a planned upgrade to the existing system and would be purchased using the Water Capital Reserves and Federal/Provincial funding.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-15
Construction End Date:2017-12-12

properties.Name: Water System Upgrades, Water Reservoir Upgrades, and New Stand-by Generators
properties.Description:
Project Description:Renewal of water storage reservoir interior and exterior coatings. Installation of two new stand-by generators (one at the water treatment plant and one at the Well No.3 Pumphouse). Water system upgrades for by-passing reservoir during maintenance/outages.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-19
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: Upgrading of the P1 and P2 sewer pumping stations -optimization of storm overflow structures

Both ponds are not functioning as designed and the outlet structures require repair to meet Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change requirements. The outlets require repairs as they management peak storm events that discharge to Millers Creek and Caruthers Creek. The ponds also have accumulated sediment to be removed offsite to improve the function of these stormwater management facilities as required by Ministry of the environment and climate change criteria. The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset. This project will help maintain the existing wetland and wildlife habitat and prevent localized flooding and erosion issues on Millers Creek and Carruthers Creek, respectively. As well as provide water quality improvements through nutrient retention and water filtration that this SWM facility provides when operating as designed. Minor or routine maintenance is garbage, debris and vegetation removal from this stormwater management facility. This project is a major repair and requires large excavation equipment and hauling away of potentially hazards material which is not routine. Due to weather-sensitive work that must be completed outside of winter months, we are requesting an extension beyond March 31, 2018, to ensure successful completion of the project.

properties.Name: Rehabilitation and Realignment of Stormwater Drains for Paget and Rolling Meadows
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project will include the rehabilitation of the existing Paget Municipal Drain and realignment of the existing Rolling Meadows Municipal Drain in order to alleviate flooding concerns upstream for properties located north of North Street. The project will provide a combined storm channel outlet into a common storm water drainage channel approximately 200 metres in length, in coordination with the reconstruction of North Street (Oxford County Road 20). This storm channel would allow the Town to abandon these two existing municipal drains and combine into a municipally-owned storm channel that will provide an outlet between North Street and the former Canadian Southern Railway Line. To facilitate the works, the existing 900 mm diameter Rolling Meadows Municipal Drain will be extended east from Falcon Road by installing 45 metres of 1200 mm diameter concrete storm sewer along the south side of North Street to a new common outlet location. 200 metres of the 400 mm diameter Paget Municipal Drain will be abandoned south of North Street as a result of the construction of the storm channel. A new concrete headwall will be installed at the north limit of the storm channel, immediately south of North Street, approximately 45 metres east of Falcon Road, to direct the flow from the relocated drains into the storm channel. The construction of the storm channel and the realignment of the two drains will eliminate the current flooding and erosion that occurs on adjacent lands during high intensity rainfall events by providing an unrestricted outlet for the upstream lands.

properties.Name: Upgrade the aeration system to diffused air from mechanical surface aeration
properties.Description:
Project Description:Aeration in a wastewater treatment plant is the process of adding oxygen into wastewater to accelerate the biological breakdown of the wastewater pollutants. The current method of aeration at Cobourg's Normar Road plant is the use of mechanical paddle aerators. This technology relies on the action of surface paddles producing plumes of droplets above the surface of the liquid in the tank. The droplets have a larger surface area for oxygen transfer from the air to the droplets than the liquid surface in the tank alone. Diffused air systems on the other hand involve the installation of piping along the bottom of the tank through which air is pumped, producing bubbles which rise to the surface transferring oxygen to the liquid. This system is superior to the mechanical paddle aerators in several ways; the oxygen transfer is more efficient, mixing is much better, and the electric motors used to power the system consume less energy than the mechanical aerator motors. The increased efficiency of the oxygen transfer process increases the capacity of the plant which postpones the need to expand the plant beyond the current expected time. Due to delays in tendering, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project. More time is required to complete the design and tendering of the project because to tender the project during the summer months when contractors are already busy will increase the cost of the project. Additionally, delivery time of the equipment required for this project cannot be guaranteed by the original end date even if we were to tender the project in the fall.
Construction Start Date:2017-06-01
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: SWPCC Biosolids System Upgrades
properties.Description:
Project Description:This project consists of the installation of a new solid bowl centrifuge and odour control equipment in the existing biosolids building. The centrifuge will require minor electrical wiring and mechanical piping modifications to the existing plant setup. The new centrifuge will replace one existing rotary press and will result in very few changes to the solids handling process upstream. Waste activated sludge will continue to be wasted to the rotary drum thickener (RDT) via the existing WAS pumps. Following thickening the sludge will drop into the blend tank where it will be combined with primary sludge prior to being fed to the centrifuge. The existing progressive cavity pumps installed in the sludge blending pump station will deliver the sludge to the new centrifuge. The scrubber will be installed between the existing two stacks of the ventilation system at the biosolids building. The scrubber will have a mist eliminator to prevent the water from escaping the stack and will be designed to be operated year round.
Construction Start Date:2017-09-01
Construction End Date:2019-03-31

properties.Name: Seaway Secondary Clarifier Upgrade (Clarifier Gearbox assemblies/scraper arms/drive motor & electrical) - located in the City of Port Colborne
properties.Description:
Project Description:"The project includes:  Replacement of clarifier gearbox assemblies  Installation of new Upper and Lower scraper arms  Replacement of drive motors and associated electrical components (including motor control center MCC) Construction was originally scheduled for 2018 but the project has been moved forward because of increased risk of failure. The project is incremental in nature in that the project had been removed from our 2017 capital budget due to insufficient regional funding required to proceed with the construction phase. The CWWF funding will allow us to proceed with a key infrastructure project. The Seaway Waste Water Treatment Plant located in the City of Port Colborne treats sewage from approximately 13,650 people plus industrial, commercial and institutional sewage generators. This Waste Water Treatment Plant is a Class 3 plant with a rated Average Daily Flow capacity of 19,600 m³/day, Peak Flow Rate (Dry Weather) of 45,360 m³/day. This treatment plant was built in 1981 and the Secondary Clarifier system has been in service continuously since that time. The plants two circular secondary clarifiers that have been in service over 35 years. These assets have passed their service life and require replacement. Currently increased maintenance efforts are required to keep the two units in operational. The cost estimate is based on a replacement estimate from a local contractor. "
Construction Start Date:2017-12-15
Construction End Date:2018-05-29

properties.Name: Stormwater Asset Management Plan
properties.Description:

The decrease of $4,139 in total project costs ($2,069 in federal CWWF funding) is due to the budgetary estimates coming in lower than anticipated for the scope of work. The scope of the project remains the same. IO NOTE: There is no decrease in scope, only a decrease in tender. This will result in a decrease in Federal Funding of $2,029 to be reallocated to IDS17-12."

properties.Name: Oakwood Street Trunk Sewer Extension Structural Construction
properties.Description:
Project Description:Oakwood Truck Sanitary Sewer is designed with capacity to service undeveloped land between Puce River and Manning Road. The line currently ends at Puce Road (County Road 25). The extension of the trunk sanitary sewer across to the west side of the Puce River was identified as a priority inn the 2009 Water and Wastewater Master Plan. Land west of the Puce River has been purchased for the extension. Growth and development of both residential and commercial to the west are currently limited and rely on the availability of this trunk crossing to the west side of the river. It is also identified as an important action initiative within Council's Strategic Priority to Maximize Development Growth Opportunities. Project consists of approx. 512m extension of the 900mm sanitary sewer trunk to the West River Road (crossing underneath the Puce River). From this point forward the lands can be reasonably developed with planning approval. Due to delays in developing the Transfer Payment Agreement and subsequent delays in procurement and its impact on construction schedule, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.

properties.Name: Refurbishment of the water intake in the Lac-sur-la-Montagne reservoir

The water main on Helena was built in 1921 and due to its age is susceptible to breaks. There have been several breaks on this section of water main. This section of water main also contains lead water services. IO NOTE: There is no decrease in scope, only a decrease in tender. Construction Start Date:2016-03-03

properties.Name: Rehabilitation of the York-Durham Sewer on 16th Avenue the City of Markham
properties.Description:
Project Description:*** Modified project. Please see notes for original project information*** This project includes the application of geopolymer mortar lining system on approximately 3 kilometers of 2.462 m diameter sanitary sewer to mitigate the current infiltration into the sewer and structurally rehabilitate the sewer. This sewer is one of the main branches of the York-Durham Sewer, which conveys sewage from Aurora, Newmarket, Markham and Richmond Hill to the Duffin Creek Water Pollution Control Plant for treatment. The current schedule for the work indicates that a reasonable construction duration with a single crew is approximately 200 m of rehabilitation per month with the current forecasted completion date of December 2018, allowing for mobilization, commissioning, testing, etc. All efforts to expedite the completion are being explored, including, but not limited to the following: multiple crews during construction, expedited procurement process, expedited design process, etc. Extension requested to December 31, 2018. 25% costs will extend beyond March 31, 2018. Increased funds requested for additional structural lining requirements to mitigate identified structural defects, required for the full length. properties.Description:

Scope: Plan, design and construct a appx 42,000 m3 stormwater surcharge retention pond, stormwater pump manhole and force main, and modify abandoned lagoons to use as additional surcharge retention adjacent to the new retention pond, and all associated works. Output: Stormwater retention pond, pumpstation, force main and decommissioned lagoons.

The construction will impact around 42 homes and the improvement will benefit approximately 70 homes. The road will be reinstalled to the same width as currently exists once the sewer and water work is completed. Other contribution funding is from Windsor Utilities Commission for water main work. Due to our deficiency hodlback standards of our warrant period we are reqeusting an extnesion beyond March 31, 2018 to succssefully complete our project.

properties.Name: Transcona Sewer Relief
properties.Description:
Project Description:Upgrade the flood protection in the Transcona Area to have no surcharge within 2.4 m of ground level for a 10-year MacLaren design storm event. Phase 3 and 4 are remaining.  These phases will complete the planned relief works for the sewer district. The 10-year MacLaren design storm event is the minimum service level standard for basement flood relief projects. It is a made in Winnipeg rainfall frequency curve. The existing basement flood protection in the Transcona sewer district is below the minimum service level established for the City of Winnipeg. The proposed works will include new sewer construction and sewer replacements that will provide the minimum level of service for basement flood protection, during the design rainfall event, in the Transcona Area.
Construction Start Date:2018-02-06
Construction End Date:2018-09-30

A portion of the sewer that runs between homes will be re-aligned within the Right-of-Way. The recommended renewal option is open cut. properties.Name: Murray Street Sanitary Sewer - Replacement of vitrified clay pipe
properties.Description:
Project Description:OBJECTIVE: The Town is actively adopting wastewater infrastructure renewal projects that improve operation and maintenance requirements, reduce inflow and infiltration, provide enhancements to the natural environment and support long term sustainable infrastructure. SCOPE: The scope of this project includes the replacement of 630 metres of 200-375mm diameter vitrified clay sanitary sewers from Aberdeen Street to Waterloo Street that were constructed in 1925. The sanitary sewer is in a poor structural state and is beyond the end of its service life, as such, replacement of the sanitary sewer is the recommended rehabilitation alternative along with the replacement of maintenance holes and sanitary laterals. Additionally, the project includes the replacement of 240 metres of 150mm diameter cast iron watermain constructed in 1920 from Aberdeen Street to Central Avenue. The watermain is beyond the end of its service life and is prone to failure leading to water quality concerns. Considering the age of the watermain, replacement of the watermain is the recommended rehabilitation alternative. This is a priority project for the Town. Town Council has accelerated this project to design in 2016 and construction in 2017 through administrative report IS-22-2016. This project was originally forecast for design in 2018 with construction forecast for 2019. This project has a planned 2017 construction start. OUTPUT: The estimated reduction in stormwater (inflow & infiltration) entering the wastewater distribution system is approximately 4,000 m3 per annum as a result of replacing the sanitary sewer, maintenance holes and service laterals. The replacement of the watermain will improve system reliability; reduce operational issues as well as reducing opportunities for negative impacts to water quality. This project will directly contribute to reduce point source sanitary overflows to meet both regulatory requirements and objectives of the remedial action plan for the Niagara River
Construction Start Date:2017-04-30
Construction End Date:2018-11-16

properties.Name: Structural upgrade to wastewater forcemain at Holditch Street extension
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project is to replacement a section of 200mm High-density Polyethylene (HDPE) sanitary force main pipe with 200mm water main quality pipe. High-density polyethylene force main pipes installed in the early 1970's has failed in several locations in town. This section for replacement is a sensitive location that crosses under the Trans-Canada Highway and a railway line. This work is a continuation of force main replacement that was made this year as part of the 2016 Holditch Storm Sewer Separation project. Further, a short section storm separation located at the north end of the 2016 project on Holditch Street will be included. Note, all work is adjacent to the 2016 Storm Separation Project, not part of the project.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-01
Construction End Date:2018-11-30

properties.Name: Bamfield Water Treatment Facility
properties.Description:
Project Description:The project works will include: - Sediment and erosion control, dewatering, clearing and grubbing, standard excavation and disposal, site grading and drainage, paving and painting, hydraulic seeding and site restoration; - Construction of water treatment plant foundation, building, HVAC and perimeter drains, security fencing and gate; - Installation of Dissolved Air Filtration, Gravity Filtration, Ultraviolet Disinfection Equipment, and Chemical injection equipment, along with necessary treatment plant appurtunances, piping and controls; and, - Electrical and Controls.
Construction Start Date:2017-05-17
Construction End Date:2018-06-30

properties.Name: French Creek Pollution Control Centre Expansion
properties.Description:
Project Description:The French Creek Pollution Control Centre (FCPCC) in the Regional District of Nanaimo (RDN) was constructed in 1978 as a conventional activated sludge wastewater treatment plant. The FCPCC was upgraded in 1996 (Stage 2) to a trickling filter/solids contact process. The Stage 3 upgrades, completed between 2006 and 2010, included modifications to the headworks, solids contact tanks, solids thickening and dewatering, and effluent pumping. Stage 4 Expansion (this project) will accommodate growth in the service area. The project will also include other upgrades to replace ageing infrastructure. The FCPCC is reaching its capacity and must ben expanded to avoid overflows and to facilitate growth in the area. The RDN requires a preliminary design report to establish the scope, schedule and cost for the FCPCC Stage 4 expansion.
Construction Start Date:2018-01-10
Construction End Date:

properties.Name: Electoral Area C Lake Errock Water System Upgrades
properties.Description:

properties.Name: Water Treatment Plant Expansion and Upgrade

Project Description:Objective: Improve drinking water quality to resolve regulatory issues. Scope: Plan, design and construct an above ground package unit that contains clarification, sedimentation and filtration treatment processes, convert the existing flocculation and sedimentation chambers to aerated raw water storage, modify existing sand filter to a manganese greensand filter, and all other associated works. Output: New package treatment plant, new building, aerated storage.

A separate area for chemical storage will improve occupational health and safety for operator. Off-reserve benefits are more secure and safe drinking water supply leading to reduced burden to provincial health care system

properties.Name: Replacement of Foundation Drain Collectors -Phase 1
properties.Description:

The foundation drain collector would be approximately 3 metres deep. Storm services will be installed from the foundation drain collector and connected to the existing foundation drain and eliminate the use of sump pumps. Due to the size and complexity of the project, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.

Construction End Date:2018-09-30

Due to regulatory requirements and/or permit delays, we are requesting an extension beyond the March 31, 2018 deadline to ensure successful completion of the project.
